'''Kurt Happy Zouma''' (born 27 October 1994) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre-back]] for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], on loan from fellow [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[France national football team|France national team]].
Zouma began his career at [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]], making his professional debut aged 16. Zouma won the [[Coupe de la Ligue]] with the club [[2013 Coupe de la Ligue Final|in 2013]], and joined Chelsea for £12 million in January 2014. Chelsea loaned him back to his first club for the remainder of the season, and in his first full campaign in England, Zouma helped Chelsea win the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] and the [[Premier League]]. In July 2017 Zouma joined [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on loan for the [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18]] season.
Zouma represented France at youth levels, up to [[France national under-21 football team|under-21]]. He made his [[France national football team|senior international]] debut against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] on 29 March 2015.
==Club career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Lyon]], Zouma began his career at age nine with Vaulx-en-Velin until he was 15. He played as a right winger and also as a striker before switching to his current position of a defender.<ref>{{cite news |title=Teenage kicks: Kurt Zouma |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/01/teenage-kicks--kurt-zouma.html |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=31 December 2014 |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
===Saint-Étienne=== Zouma joined [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] in 2009. On 2 April 2011, he signed his first professional contract, agreeing to a three-year deal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kurt Zouma signe pro à Saint-Etienne |url=http://www.footransferts.com/index.php/2011/04/kurt-zouma-signe-pro-a-saint-etienne/ |work=Foot Transferts |date=2 April 2011 |accessdate=31 August 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120730094958/http://www.footransferts.com/index.php/2011/04/kurt-zouma-signe-pro-a-saint-etienne/ |archivedate=30 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> He was subsequently promoted to the senior team by [[Coach (sport)|manager]] [[Christophe Galtier]] ahead of the [[2011–12 in French football|2011–12 season]], and initially played without a name on his shirt in order to protect him from media attention.<ref name=four/>
Zouma made his professional debut at 16 years old, on 31 August 2011 in a [[Coupe de la Ligue]] match against [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], playing the entire match in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saint-Étienne v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuille_match/75397 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=31 August 2011 |accessdate=31 August 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916074223/http://new.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuille_match/75397 |archivedate=16 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> On 17 September, he made his [[Ligue 1]] debut in a 3–0 loss at [[FC Lorient|Lorient]]; his first professional goal came on 19 November, replacing [[Paulo Afonso Santos Júnior|Paulão]] after nine minutes and finishing a [[corner kick]] to confirm a 2–0 win before half time at [[OGC Nice]].<ref>{{cite news|title=NICE 0–2 SAINT-ETIENNE|url=http://www.ogcnice.com/fr/actualite/7201/nice-0-2-saint-etienne|accessdate=4 May 2016|publisher=OGC Nice|date=19 November 2011|language=French}}</ref> He totalled 21 league games in his first season – 13 starts – and his other goal came on 14 January 2012, heading [[Banel Nicolita]]'s corner for the only goal against lowly [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] at the [[Stade Geoffroy-Guichard]].<ref>{{cite news|title=St. Etienne edges troubled Sochaux|url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/st-etienne-1-0-sochaux-match-report-ligue-1-zouma-nets-game-winner-011412|accessdate=4 May 2016|publisher=Fox Sports|date=14 January 2012}}</ref>
On 20 April 2013, Zouma played in Saint-Étienne's 1–0 win over [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]] in the [[2013 Coupe de la Ligue Final|final]] of the Coupe de la Ligue.<ref>{{cite web|title=AS Saint-Etienne 1–0 Stade Rennais FC|url=http://www.ligue1.com/coupeLigue/feuille_match/77456|publisher=[[Ligue 1]]}}</ref> Eight days later in the [[Derby du Rhone]] away to [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]], he opened a 1–1 draw by heading [[Yohan Mollo]]'s corner after half an hour of play.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lyon on course for third|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/lyon-vs-st-etienne/285668|accessdate=4 May 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 April 2013}}</ref> On 7 November 2013, Zouma was banned for ten games following a challenge that left [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]]'s [[Thomas Guerbert]] with a broken right leg and a dislocated ankle.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Devine|first1=Chris|title=Zouma given 10-match ban following horror tackle|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/90/france/2013/11/07/4391643/zouma-given-10-match-ban-following-horror-tackle|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=Goal.com|date=7 November 2013}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== ====2014–15 season==== [[File:Chelsea 1 lLiverpool 0 (2-1 agg) Capital One Cup semi final 2nd leg On our way to Wembley! (16204857347).jpg|thumb|right|175px|Zouma holding a banner celebrating Chelsea reaching the [[2015 Football League Cup Final]]]] On 31 January 2014, Zouma joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a five-and-a-half-year contract for a fee believed to be around £12 million (€14.6 million).<ref name=twelve>{{cite news|title=Transfer Deadline Day: Kurt Zouma joins Chelsea for £12m|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25973862|accessdate=29 January 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 January 2014}}</ref> He remained at Saint-Étienne on loan for the remainder of the [[2013–14 Ligue 1|2013–14 season]].<ref name=twelve/>
Zouma first appeared as a first-half substitute for Chelsea in a pre-season friendly against [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]]. He scored his first goal for the club in a 2–1 friendly win against Slovene club [[Olimpija Ljubljana|Olimpija]], on 27 July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/07/match-report--nk-olimpija-ljubljana-1-chelsea-2.html|title=Match report: NK Olimpija Ljubljana 1 Chelsea 2|publisher=[[Chelsea F.C.]]|date=27 July 2014|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref> He was given the number 5 shirt, previously worn by [[Michael Essien]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Squad number changes|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/squad-number-changes.html?WT.mc_id=social_20140815_29820286|publisher=[[Chelsea F.C.]]|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>
On 24 September, Zouma made his first competitive appearance for Chelsea, scoring the opener in a 2–1 win against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in the third round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 2–1 Bolton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29233095|accessdate=24 September 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 September 2014}}</ref> He made his second Chelsea start and first [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] appearance on 21 October against [[NK Maribor|Maribor]], helping his side keep a clean sheet in a 6–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29362738 |title=Didier Drogba scored his first goal since rejoining Chelsea as they recorded their biggest-ever Champions League win with a dominant victory against Maribor at Stamford Bridge. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 October 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2014 }}</ref> He made his Premier League debut as an added-time substitute for [[Willian (footballer)|Willian]] in the 1–1 draw with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]] on 26 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29679403 |title=Manchester United 1–1 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 October 2014 |accessdate=26 October 2014 }}</ref>
On 4 January 2015, Zouma scored the third goal for Chelsea in the 3–0 victory over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 3–0 Watford|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30614332|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 January 2015}}</ref> Six days later, he started in the Premier League for the first time, partnering [[John Terry]] in place of [[Gary Cahill]] and keeping a clean sheet in a 2–0 home win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], which put Chelsea back into first place in the league table.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reddy|first1=Luke|title=Chelsea 2–0 Newcastle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30663822|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2015}}</ref> With [[Nemanja Matić]] suspended and [[John Obi Mikel]] injured, Zouma played in defensive midfield as Chelsea won the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]] on 1 March after a 2–0 victory over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31572594|accessdate=2 March 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 March 2015}}</ref> On 3 May, he featured as a substitute for the final five minutes in place of Willian as Chelsea defeated [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] 1–0 to win the league title.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Chelsea 1–0 Crystal Palace|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32471261|accessdate=14 May 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 May 2015}}</ref>
====2015–17==== [[File:Newcastle United vs Chelsea, 26 September 2015 (10).JPG|thumb|Zouma in action against Newcastle in September 2015]] On 2 August 2015, Zouma was a 69th-minute substitute for [[César Azpilicueta]] as Chelsea lost 1–0 to [[Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|rivals]] [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2015 FA Community Shield|Community Shield]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cryer|first1=Andy|title=Arsenal 1–0 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667216|accessdate=2 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 August 2015}}</ref> Starting ahead of John Terry, he scored his first Premier League goal on 19 September, heading in [[Cesc Fàbregas]]' cross to open a 2–0 home win over the same opposition.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Chelsea 2–0 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34191867|accessdate=20 September 2015|date=19 September 2015}}</ref> On 24 November, as a late substitute for the injured Terry, he scored his first European goal to conclude a 4–0 win at [[Maccabi Tel Aviv]] in the Champions League [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rose|first1=Gary|title=M'bi Tel Aviv 0–4 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34896622|accessdate=25 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 November 2015}}</ref>
Under interim manager [[Guus Hiddink]], Zouma regularly started alongside Terry as Chelsea's form improved. On 7 February 2016, Zouma ruptured the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee after landing awkwardly from a jump in a match against [[Manchester United]]. He required surgery and was ruled out for six months.<ref name=injury>{{cite news|title=Kurt Zouma: Chelsea defender out for six months & needs surgery|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35527443|accessdate=9 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 February 2016}}</ref>
In the summer of 2016, Zouma traveled and trained with the first-team during preseason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/zouma--coming-back-stronger.html |title=Zouma: Coming back stronger |date=20 July 2016 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.}}</ref> Chelsea also rejected a loan offer from [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/704672/Chelsea-Antonio-Conte-Schalke-Kurt-Zouma-Premier-League-John-Terry-Gary-Cahill-News |title=Chelsea in talks with Schalke over transfer of young defender |date=28 August 2016|work=Daily Express}}</ref> On 24 October, Zouma made his first competitive appearance after being out of action for nine months, playing 45 minutes for the [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|Chelsea under-23]] side in a 2–2 draw against Derby County.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/10/pl2-report--chelsea-v-derby-county.html |title=PL2 report: Chelsea 2 Derby 2 |date=24 October 2016 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.}}</ref> On 8 January 2017, Zouma made his first team comeback in Chelsea's 4–1 [[2016–17 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third-round win over [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/08/chelsea-peterborough-united-fa-cup-match-report|title=John Terry sees red but comfortable Chelsea ease past Peterborough|date=9 January 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref> On 4 February, he made his first appearance of the [[2016–17 Premier League]] season as a substitute in a 3–1 win against rivals [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2017/feb/04/chelsea-arsenal-premier-league-live|title=Chelsea 3–1 Arsenal|date=1 March 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
====2017–18 season: Loan to Stoke City==== Following agreeing to a new six-year deal with Chelsea, on 21 July 2017, Zouma joined fellow Premier League side [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on loan for the [[2017–18 Stoke City F.C. season|2017–18]] season.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Zouma signs new deal and heads to Stoke |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/new-contract-and-loan-for-zouma.html |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=21 July 2017 |accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kurt Zouma: Chelsea defender joins Stoke on season-long loan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40684771|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> On 12 August, he made his debut in a 1–0 loss at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/everton-vs-stoke/373101 |title=Everton 1–0 Stoke |date=12 August 2017 |publisher=SkySports}}</ref>
In November 2017, Stoke captain [[Ryan Shawcross]] expressed his surprise that Chelsea had loaned out Zouma, who had only missed one match, against his parent club.<ref name=shawcross>{{cite news|title=Ryan Shawcross surprised Chelsea allowed 'ultimate defender' Kurt Zouma to leave on loan|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11701/11128404/ryan-shawcross-surprised-chelsea-allowed-ultimate-defender-kurt-zouma-to-leave-on-loan|accessdate=26 November 2017|publisher=Sky Sports|date=16 November 2017}}</ref> On 20 November he headed his first goal for the Potters, in a 2–2 draw at [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bysouth|first1=Alex|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–2 Stoke City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41964596|accessdate=26 November 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 November 2017}}</ref> Zouma played 37 matches for Stoke in 2017–18 as the club suffered relegation to the [[EFL Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Swansea 1–2 Stoke|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44020155|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season: Loan to Everton==== On 10 August 2018, Zouma joined fellow Premier League side [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on loan for the [[2018–19 Everton F.C. season|2018–19]] season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2018/08/10/zouma|title=Zouma Joins Everton On Season-Long Loan|date=10 August 2018|accessdate=10 August 2018|publisher=Everton Official Site}}</ref> He made his debut on 25 August as a last-minute substitute for the injured [[Michael Keane (footballer, born 1993)|Michael Keane]] in a 2–2 draw at [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sutcliffe |first1=Steve |title=Bournemouth 2–2 Everton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45230638 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 August 2018}}</ref>
Zouma scored his first goal for Everton on 13 January 2019, a header to open a 2–0 home win also against Bournemouth.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hunter |first1=Andy |title=Kurt Zouma nods home to steer Everton towards nervy win over Bournemouth |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/13/everton-bournemouth-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=17 February 2019 |work=The Guardian |date=13 January 2019}}</ref> He was sent off for dissent after the final whistle in a 1–0 loss at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 9 February.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Prentice |first1=David |title=Everton defender Kurt Zouma red-carded AFTER the final whistle at Watford |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-defender-kurt-zouma-red-15806796 |accessdate=17 February 2019 |work=Liverpool Echo |date=9 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Zouma is a [[France national youth football team|France youth international]] having represented his nation at [[France national under-16 football team|under-16]] and [[France national under-17 football team|under-17]] level. He played with the under-17 team at the [[2011 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] and [[2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup]]. Zouma has been the captain for the [[France national under-21 football team|French under-21]] side.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zouma strike makes it a perfect six for France|url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2015/matches/round=2000412/match=2011566/postmatch/report/index.html|publisher=UEFA|date=4 March 2014}}</ref> He was part of the [[France national under-20 football team|under-20 team]] that won the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2013 World Cup]] in Turkey. In the quarter-finals against [[Uzbekistan national under-20 football team|Uzbekistan]] in [[Rize]], he headed the last goal of a 4–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Uzbeks no match for in-form France|url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=259231/match=300234903/match-report.html|accessdate=4 May 2016|publisher=FIFA|date=6 July 2013}}</ref>
Senior France manager [[Didier Deschamps]] wanted to build a defence around Zouma and fellow youngster [[Raphaël Varane]],<ref name=four/> and on 19 March 2015, he was called him up for the first time for friendlies against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holyman|first1=Ian|title=Nabil Fekir and Kurt Zouma named in France squad for friendlies|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/international-friendly/story/2356374/nabil-fekir-and-kurt-zouma-named-in-france-squad-for-friendlies|accessdate=20 March 2015|publisher=ESPN|date=19 March 2015}}</ref> He made his debut in the latter match ten days later, a 2–0 win at his former club ground with Saint-Étienne, the [[Stade Geoffroy-Guichard]], replacing [[Morgan Schneiderlin]] for the last eight minutes of the game.<ref>{{cite news|title=France 2–0 Denmark: Lacazette and Giroud on target|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/france-vs-denmark/1703395/report?ICID=MP_MS_5|accessdate=29 March 2015|work=Goal.com|date=29 March 2015}}</ref> After his injury for Chelsea in February, Zouma missed France's hosting of [[UEFA Euro 2016]].<ref name=injury/>
He returned to the squad in August 2017, replacing the injured [[Raphaël Varane]] for a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|World Cup qualifier]] against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/world-cup-qualifying-uefa/story/3190974/stoke-defender-kurt-zouma-replaces-raphael-varane-in-france-squad |title=Stoke defender Kurt Zouma replaces Raphael Varane in France squad |date=28 August 2017 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> He was put on standby for France's squad at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|final tournament]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Benson|first1=Michael|title=World Cup 2018: Chelsea, Manchester United and Manchester City stars included in France's squad for finals|url=https://talksport.com/football/world-cup-2018-chelsea-manchester-united-and-manchester-city-stars-included-frances-squad|accessdate=24 May 2018|publisher=Talksport|date=17 May 2018}}</ref> Zouma earned his first France cap in over three years on 11 October 2018 as a substitute in a 2–2 friendly draw with [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]], coming on as a substitute and winning the equalising penalty.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Pringle |first1=Ben |title=Chelsea player ratings – International break: Morata and Giroud flop again, Ampadu injured |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1030543/Chelsea-player-ratings-international-break-Morata-Giroud-Ampadu |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Daily Express |date=12 October 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== [[File:Kurt Zouma (03-08-2011).jpg|thumb|right|150px|Zouma with Saint-Étienne in 2011]] A November 2013 report by ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' noted Zouma's strength, reading of the game, and aerial presence, while mentioning his occasional lapses in concentration.<ref name=four>{{cite news|last1=Simon|first1=Tim|title=Everything you need to know about... Kurt Zouma|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/everything-you-need-know-about-kurt-zouma#:LTIsiA1MqkpNyA|accessdate=4 May 2016|work=FourFourTwo|date=13 November 2013}}</ref> In January 2014, Zouma was named by British newspaper ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the ten most promising young players in Europe. The newspaper wrote, "Blessed with exceptional power and technique, Zouma is also coveted by many for his leadership qualities."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/jan/19/next-10-big-things-europes-top-youngsters|title=The next 10 big things: Europe's top youngsters and stars of the future|date=18 January 2014|work=The Observer}}</ref>
''[[Match of the Day]]'' pundit, [[Danny Murphy (footballer, born 1977)|Danny Murphy]] linked Zouma to [[Marcel Desailly]], another Frenchman who played in defence for Chelsea. Writing after a draw with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], which included a strong run and perfectly-executed sliding tackle on [[Sergio Agüero]], Murphy noted Zouma's reliability and confidence against the strong opponent, in addition to his pace. He predicted that Zouma could be a Chelsea mainstay for years to come, and would be an ideal replacement for captain [[John Terry]], then aged 34.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Danny|title=Chelsea 1–1 Man City: 'Kurt Zouma reminds me of Marcel Desailly'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31078757|accessdate=1 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2015}}</ref>
Shawcross called Zouma the "ultimate defender" for his speed, jump, passing, shooting and tackling, and said that [[Tottenham Hotspur]]'s [[Toby Alderweireld]] was the only central defender on his level.<ref name=shawcross/>
==Personal life== Zouma's parents emigrated to France from the [[Central African Republic]].<ref>{{cite news|title=France: Kurt Zouma parle de la paix en Centrafrique|trans-title=France: Kurt Zouma speaks of peace in the Central African Republic|url=http://www.journaldebangui.com/article.php?aid=7416|accessdate=28 August 2015|work=Journal de Bangui|date=8 October 2014|language=French}}</ref> His older brother [[Lionel Zouma|Lionel]] plays in the same position for French club [[Football Bourg-en-Bresse Péronnas 01|Bourg-en Bresse]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Les retrouvailles des " jumeaux " Zouma|trans-title=The reunion of the Zouma "twins"|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/espace-premium/sports/les-retrouvailles-des-jumeaux-zouma-23-03-2014-3697943.php|accessdate=29 January 2015|work=[[Le Parisien]]|date=23 March 2014|language=French}}</ref> Zouma is named after Kurt Sloane, [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]]'s character in the 1989 film [[Kickboxer (1989 film)|''Kickboxer'']], while his middle name Happy reflects an African tradition of using positive words as middle names.<ref>{{cite news|last1=de Menezes|first1=Jack|title=Chelsea vs Aston Villa: Kurt Zouma reveals he is named after Jean-Claude Van Damme...and why he has reason to smile all the time|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chelsea-vs-aston-villa-kurt-zouma-reveals-he-is-named-after-jean-claude-van-dammeand-why-he-has-9755954.html|accessdate=4 May 2016|work=The Independent|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> Zouma is married to Sandra, with whom he has two children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Photo: Chelsea star relaxes with his kids at Stamford Bridge|url=http://www.thesportreview.com/tsr/2015/12/photo-chelsea-star-relaxes-with-his-kids-at-stamford-bridge/|accessdate=9 February 2016|work=The Sports Review|date=20 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea star Kurt Zouma takes his family to Disneyland Paris|url=http://www.espnfc.us/blog/the-toe-poke/65/post/2794277/chelsea-star-kurt-zouma-takes-his-family-to-disneyland-paris|accessdate=9 February 2016|work=[[ESPN]] Soccer |author=Liam Twomey|date=26 January 2016}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=October 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Phil Jagielka | image = Phil Jagielka 2015-07-18 1.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Jagielka playing for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in 2015 | fullname = Philip Nikodem Jagielka<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|8|17|df=y}}<ref name=Hugman1011>{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=216}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Manchester]], England | height = {{convert|1.83|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |title=2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil: List of players: England |url=http://www.fifadata.com/document/fwc/2014/pdf/fwc_2014_squadlists.pdf |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=14 |date=14 July 2014 |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> | position = [[Centre-back]] | currentclub = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | clubnumber = 6 | youthyears1 = 1998–2000 | youthclubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C. Academy|Sheffield United]] | years1 = 2000–2007 | clubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] | caps1 = 254 | goals1 = 18 | years2 = 2007– | clubs2 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | caps2 = 318 | goals2 = 13 | nationalyears1 = 2002–2003 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2007 | nationalteam2 = [[England national football B team|England B]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2008– | nationalteam3 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps3 = 40 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | club-update = 13:20, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:50, 27 August 2018 (UTC) }} '''Philip Nikodem Jagielka''' ({{IPAc-en|j|ə|ˈ|ɡ|j|ɛ|l|k|ə}}<ref>{{Citation|last=FATV|title=Phil Jagielka Special – Everton v Chelsea (2015/16 Emirates FA Cup) {{!}} FATV Focus|date=11 March 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y98EvmMIK4A&t=10s|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=FATV|title=Which superhero would Phil Jagielka be? {{!}} Gone in 60 Seconds|date=14 June 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIiHobspcTE&t=4s|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> or {{IPAc-en|ˌ|dʒ|æ|ɡ|i|ˈ|ɛ|l|k|ə}};<ref>{{Citation|last=England Football Official|title=Jagielka goal – England v Peru {{!}} Goals & Highlights|date=31 May 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ymq7wLmHuts&t=18s|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=NBC Sports|title=Phil Jagielka rises to give Everton a 3–2 lead|date=9 April 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mA2pH-l1Ztk&t=6s|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref> born 17 August 1982) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre-back]] for {{English football updater|Everton}} club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. Jagielka is also the captain of Everton.
Jagielka started his career with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in 2000, where he played mainly as a [[central midfielder]]. He helped them achieve top-flight status for the [[2006–07 Sheffield United F.C. season|2006–07 season]], after which he joined Everton for a £4 million fee.
He has received 40 England caps since his debut in 2008 and was included in the England squads at [[UEFA Euro 2012]] and the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].
==Early life== Jagielka was born in [[Manchester]]<ref name=Hugman1011/> and attended [[Knutsford Academy]]. He played for Holy Family Football Club, a Sunday team affiliated with, although not directly linked to, the school of the same name, from the ages of eight to 11. He played as a right winger, as he possessed great pace, and even played in matches against boys of the school year older than him. However, he first impressed youth scouts whilst playing for his local team [[Hale Barns]] United in [[Altrincham]]. He predominantly played midfield during his time with the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1132676/From-time-keeper-England-centre-half--rise-rise-Phil-Jagielka.html|title=From time keeper England centre half rise rise PhilJagielka|accessdate=20 March 2009 | location=London | newspaper=Daily Mail | first=Matt | last=Lawton | date=1 February 2009}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=June 2017}} He also played for his school team, Moorlands Junior School, playing any position including in goal and with boys 2 school years above him.<ref>Moorlands Junior School</ref> He was at the academy of [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] as a youngster and spent time training with clubs such as [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], before joining [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in 1998 at 15 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shail|first=Mark|title=Jagielka has got his sights set on the Premiership|url=http://www.givemefootball.com/championship/jagielka-has-got-his-sights-set-on-the-premiership|publisher=givemefootball.com|accessdate=1 May 2011|date=17 November 2005}}{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Sheffield United=== Jagielka made his way through the youth ranks at Sheffield United before making his first-team debut on 5 May 2000 against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] in the final [[Football League First Division|First Division]] match of the [[1999–2000 Sheffield United F.C. season|1999–2000 season]], whilst still a trainee. He was rewarded with a professional contract the following day and having progressed well at the start of the following season, he signed a three-year deal with the club in January 2001.<ref>{{cite news |title=Warnock hails teenage ace |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/1108377.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 January 2001 |accessdate=21 August 2007}}</ref>
He established himself in the Sheffield United first-team in the [[2002–03 Sheffield United F.C. season|2002–03 season]] and started to attract the attention of other clubs, including [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], who were linked with a £6 million joint bid for Jagielka and United teammate [[Michael Brown (footballer, born 1977)|Michael Brown]], but Sheffield United said they would resist any attempts to sign the players.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blades deny Leeds approach |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/3153119.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2003 |accessdate=21 August 2007}}</ref>
Jagielka stated in April 2005 he was happy to stay at United, despite several [[Premier League]] clubs being interested in signing him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jagielka wants to stay at Blades |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4432967.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 April 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2007}}</ref> United manager [[Neil Warnock]] told [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in June 2005 that Jagielka would not be sold,<ref>{{cite news |title=Blades warn Hammers off Jagielka |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4115204.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 June 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2007}}</ref> and in July [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] made a £4 million bid for Jagielka, after which United upped their valuation of him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jewell unhappy over Jagielka bid |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4724037.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 July 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2007}}</ref> By November, Jagielka had been linked with a £4 million move to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], but United manager Neil Warnock said there had been no contact from Bolton.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fudge|first1=Simon|title=Blades deny fresh Jags links|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11672/2353563/blades-deny-fresh-jags-links|accessdate=9 January 2016|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
Jagielka signed a new three-year deal with United in August 2006.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jagielka commits future to Blades |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/5266726.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 August 2006 |accessdate=22 August 2007}}</ref> He played as team captain in [[Chris Morgan (footballer)|Chris Morgan]]'s absence. Jagielka gave United their first Premier League victory since April 1994 when he hit a 91st minute half-volley against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] for a 2–1 win in September 2006.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sheff Utd 2–1 Middlesbrough |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/5373476.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 September 2006 |accessdate=7 August 2007 |first=Sophie |last=Brown}}</ref> Despite being recognised as one of United's key players, chairman [[Kevin McCabe (businessman)|Kevin McCabe]] admitted that Jagielka could be sold if the price was high enough.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blades may sell Jagielka |url=http://www.football.co.uk/sheffield_united/blades_may_sell_jagielka_238477.shtml |publisher=Football.co.uk |date=8 December 2006 |accessdate=22 August 2007}}</ref> In a home match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 30 December 2006, due to a thigh injury to starting goalkeeper [[Paddy Kenny]] and with his team 1–0 up, Jagielka was forced to play in goal for the remainder of the match. Arsenal were kept at bay for the remaining 34 minutes and Jagielka's late save from [[Robin van Persie]] secured the 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sheff Utd 1–0 Arsenal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6205685.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 December 2006 |accessdate=7 August 2007}}</ref> His ability to deputise in goal meant that Neil Warnock was able to – and usually did – do without a substitute goalkeeper on the bench in order to give himself more tactical options (League rules then limited the number of substitutes to 5).
By the end of the [[2006–07 Sheffield United F.C. season|2006–07 season]], he had made 133 consecutive league appearances for United,<ref>{{cite web|title=The lowdown – Everton v Wigan|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/the-lowdown-everton-v-wigan.html|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=22 August 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930022736/http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/the-lowdown-everton-v-wigan.html|archivedate=30 September 2012|date=10 August 2007}}</ref> including every league match in the [[2004–05 Sheffield United F.C. season|2004–05]] and [[2005–06 Sheffield United F.C. season|2005–06]] seasons and every minute of the 2006–07 season.<ref name=guardian070512/> When Sheffield United were relegated from the Premier League at the end of the 2006–07 season, Jagielka was linked with moves away from United and goalkeeper Paddy Kenny said he believed it was time Jagielka moved on.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kenny feels Jagielka should leave |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/6709039.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 May 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2007}}</ref> New United boss [[Bryan Robson]] urged Jagielka to wait for the outcome of the club's relegation arbitration hearing before deciding to leave the club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blades call to Jagielka |url=http://www.football.co.uk/sheffield_united/blades_call_to_jagielka_247725.shtml |publisher=Football.co.uk |date=12 June 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2007}}</ref>
===Everton=== ====2007–2012==== [[File:Phil Jagielka 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Jagielka playing for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in 2011]]
Jagielka eventually signed for Everton on 4 July 2007, in a deal worth £4 million on a five-year contract,<ref>{{cite news |title=Everton secure deal for Jagielka |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/e/everton/6270146.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 July 2007 |accessdate=4 July 2007}}</ref> the highest amount ever paid for a Sheffield United player.<ref>{{cite news|last=Prentice|first=David|title=Jagielka factfile|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/other-sport/jagielka-factfile-3480991|newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=12 July 2008|accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> He made his home debut at [[Goodison Park]] on 31 July 2007 as a second-half substitute in a pre-season friendly against [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]], replacing [[Joseph Yobo]] in central defence. After a slow start to his Everton career, Jagielka developed into an important member of the first team. He scored his first Everton goal in the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] against [[AZ Alkmaar]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/7145803.stm |title=AZ Alkmaar 2–3 Everton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 December 2007 |accessdate=27 February 2010 |first=Caroline |last=Cheese}}</ref> He scored an own goal against Wigan Athletic, although Everton won 2–1. He put in a succession of man of the match performances in the following matches, against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], [[SK Brann|Brann]] and Manchester City. He scored his first league goal for Everton against Reading on 9 February 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7223966.stm |title=Everton 1–0 Reading |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 February 2008 |accessdate=27 February 2010 |first=Ian |last=Hughes}}</ref>
Jagielka started the 2008–09 season as first-choice centre back, playing every minute of every league match until being injured in a 2–1 home defeat to Manchester City. He was named the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for February<ref name=PL>{{cite web |title=Phil Jagielka: Overview |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/3222/Phil-Jagielka/overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> and won Everton's fans and club player of the season.<ref name=evertonawards>{{cite web|title=Awards Winners|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/content/history/players-and-managers/awards-winners|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref> Jagielka scored the winning penalty for Everton in a penalty shoot-out in the semi-final of the [[FA Cup]] against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], but he was claimed to have fouled [[Danny Welbeck]] after 68 minutes, with many claiming it to be a penalty, which the referee did not award.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/7990227.stm|title=Man Utd 0–0 Everton (aet) |date=19 January 2009|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 April 2009}}</ref> Soon afterwards he ruptured his [[anterior cruciate ligament]] playing against Manchester City, and as a consequence missed the [[2009 FA Cup Final]], which Everton lost to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].
After missing the end of the 2008–09 season and more than half of 2009–10, Jagielka played his first senior fixture since the cruciate ligament injury in an away match against [[Sporting CP]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]] in February 2010, coming on as a substitute for an injured [[Philippe Senderos]].
====2013–present==== [[File:Phil Jagielka 2014.jpg|thumb|upright|Jagielka playing for Everton in 2014]]
On 3 January 2013, Jagielka signed a new contract at Everton, keeping him at Goodison Park until 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=England defender Phil Jagielka signs new long-term Everton contract|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/03/everton-phil-jagielka-new-contract|accessdate=3 January 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=3 January 2013}}</ref> In April 2013, manager [[David Moyes]] announced that Jagielka would be appointed as the club captain for the [[2013–14 Everton F.C. season|2013–14 season]] after the retirement of [[Phil Neville]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Phil Jagielka to succeed departing Phil Neville as Everton captain|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/8633931/phil-jagielka-to-succeed-departing-phil-neville-as-everton-captain|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref>
When Moyes left for Manchester United, new manager [[Roberto Martínez]] stated that Jagielka would make a "phenomenal captain".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.football365.com/everton/8778099/Premier-League-Everton-boss-Roberto-Martinez-backs-Phil-Jagielka-as-captain | title=Martinez: Jagielka suits role | publisher=Football365.com | accessdate=29 June 2013}}</ref> In Jagielka's first season as captain, Everton amassed a Premier League club record 72 points to finish fifth<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailypost.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/phil-jagielka-everton-even-stronger-7162257 |title=Phil Jagielka: Everton will be even stronger next season under Roberto Martínez |newspaper=North Wales Daily Post |accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> with him being awarded three accolades at the club: Player of the Season, Players' Player of the Season and Goal of the Season.<ref name=evertonprofile>{{cite web|title=Phil Jagielka|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/players/p/pj/phil-jagielka|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref>
On 27 September 2014, Jagielka scored his first goal in two seasons with a 30-yard half volley against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the [[Merseyside derby]] to level the match in the 91st minute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/349943.html |title=Jagielka stunner steals a point after pulsating derby |publisher=ESPN |date=27 September 2014 |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> On 6 November 2014, Jagielka scored his first European goal in seven years in Everton's 3–0 UEFA Europa League group stage win against [[Lille OSC|Lille]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hunter|first1=Andy|title=Leon Osman marks new deal with a goal as Everton cruise to win over Lille|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/nov/06/everton-lille-europa-league-match-report|accessdate=6 November 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=6 November 2014}}</ref>
Jagielka reclaimed his place as Everton's starting centre back in March 2017 after [[Ramiro Funes Mori]] suffered a knee injury on international duty.<ref>{{cite news |title=2016–17 Everton Player Reviews: Phil Jagielka |url=https://royalbluemersey.sbnation.com/2017/6/7/15745936/phil-jagielka-season-review-everton-ronald-koeman-ashley-williams-ramiro-funes-mori |publisher=Royal Blue Mersey |date=7 June 2017 |accessdate=1 July 2017}}</ref> In April 2017, Jagielka scored in three successive league matches for Everton: first, in a 1–1 draw against Manchester United at [[Old Trafford]] on 4 April – his first league goal in two years – then in a 4–2 victory against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] at Goodison Park on 9 April, and finally, in a 3–1 home victory over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 15 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39414200|title=Manchester United 1–1 Everton |date=4 April 2017 |accessdate=4 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |last=Hafez |first=Shamoon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39470449|title=Everton 4–2 Leicester City |date=9 April 2017 |accessdate=9 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |last=Henson |first=Mike}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39536681|title=Everton 3–1 Burnley |date=15 April 2017 |accessdate=15 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |last=Whalley |first=Mike}}</ref>
Jagielka extended his contract with Everton for another year until the summer of 2019 on 2 August 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Blues Deal For Jagielka|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/08/02/new-blues-deal-for-jagielka|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Jagielka is a former member of the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] team, and scored in a 2–0 victory over [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|Slovakia]] at the [[Stadium of Light]] in June 2003.<ref>{{cite news|title=England U21s keep hopes alive|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/england/2976038.stm|accessdate=9 January 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 June 2003}}</ref>
On 10 May 2007, Jagielka was named in the [[England national football B team|England B team]] for the first time, for their match against [[Albania national football team|Albania]]. Starting on the bench, he replaced Phil Neville at right back at the beginning of the second half. On 11 May 2008, Jagielka was named in the [[England national football team|senior England squad]] for the first time for the friendlies with [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and [[Trinidad and Tobago national football team|Trinidad and Tobago]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/7395247.stm |title=Hart & Jagielka in England squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2008 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> He subsequently expressed his delight at the call up<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2008/05/13/jags-england-delight |title=Jags' England Delight |publisher=Everton F.C. |date=13 May 2008 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> and publicly thanked everyone at Everton for their help. On 1 June 2008, Jagielka got his first international cap for the senior team against Trinidad and Tobago, playing the second half of a match in which England used two different sides for each half.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trinidad & Tobago 0–3 England|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/7425208.stm|accessdate=9 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 June 2008}}</ref>
Jagielka was once again named in the England squad for the friendly match against European champions Spain, 11 February 2009, and subsequently played for the first 45 minutes, after an impressive string of performances at club level publicly praised by manager David Moyes after the FA Cup fourth round replay tie between Everton and Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_4898063,00.html|title=David Moyes has praised Phil Jagielka after his performance in the FA Cup win over Liverpool|author=Bailey, Richard|date=5 February 2009|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> Jagielka received his fourth cap when he played in England's first post 2010 FIFA World Cup friendly against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] on 11 August 2010 at Wembley Stadium where he scored an own goal to put the visitors ahead in a 2–1 England win.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gerrard brace saves England from embarrassment |url=http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/38775.html |publisher=ESPN |date=11 August 2010 |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref>
On 3 September 2010, Jagielka made his first competitive start, and played for the entirety of the match in a 4–0 win over Bulgaria. He was said to have "read the game brilliantly on a night when he proved his credentials".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Daily-Mirror-player-ratings-England-4-0-Bulgaria-Joe-Hart-Phil-Jagielka-and-James-Milner-shine-but-Jermaine-Defoe-takes-Man-of-the-Match-award-article571573.html|title=Daily Mirror player ratings: England 4–0 Bulgaria|date=3 September 2010|newspaper=Daily Mirror|location=London|accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> He was called up to the England squad once again for the Euro 2012 qualifier against [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 12 October.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/9056797.stm |publisher=BBC Sport | title=Capello calls up striker Davies | date=4 October 2010}}</ref> He was called up again for the UEFA Euro 2012 qualifier and friendly against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] and [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 26 March and came on in the 88th minute for [[Scott Parker]]. On 12 November, he started as centre-half in a friendly against Spain and gave an exceptional performance as England ground their way to a 1–0 win.
Jagielka was originally placed on the standby list for England's [[UEFA Euro 2012]] squad,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18081125 | title=England Euro 2012 squad: Ruddy, Carroll & Defoe in, Ferdinand out |publisher=BBC Sport | date=16 May 2012 | accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> and played the full match in a pre-tournament warm-up match against [[Norway national football team|Norway]], which England won 1–0.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18184726 | title=Norway 0–1 England |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref> However, on 28 May 2012, Jagielka was added to the [[UEFA Euro 2012 squads#England|main squad]] after [[Gareth Barry]] was ruled out of the tournament with an abdominal injury.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18232535 | title=Euro 2012: England confirm squad numbers |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref> Jagielka did not feature in any of England's four matches during the tournament.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2012/teams/team=39/index.html | title=England Squad | publisher=UEFA | accessdate=16 August 2012}}</ref>
In August 2012, Jagielka scored his first goal for England, a diving header during a 2–1 friendly victory over [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in [[Bern]], Switzerland.<ref name="England 2–1 Italy">{{cite news |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19238374 |title=England 2–1 Italy |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2012 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
On 12 May 2014, Jagielka was named in England's squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/12/england-world-cup-squad-hodgson-barkley-sterling |title=England World Cup squad 2014: Ross Barkley and Raheem Sterling called up |date=12 May 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> He scored his second England goal on 30 May 2014 to wrap up a 3–0 friendly win over [[Peru national football team|Peru]] at Wembley, reacting after goalkeeper [[Raúl Fernández (footballer)|Raúl Fernández]] dropped a corner from Jagielka's Everton teammate [[Leighton Baines]].<ref name="England 3–0 Peru">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 3–0 Peru |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27383301 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2014 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> England were unbeaten in 11 competitive matches in which Jagielka has played in (won eight and drawn three), until they lost 2–1 to Italy in their opening match of the World Cup.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2014/article-2624125/Phil-Jagielka-England-World-Cup-profile.html |title=Phil Jagielka – England World Cup profile |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=June 2017}}<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25285071 |title=England 1–2 Italy |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=14 June 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref>
Jagielka scored his third England goal, and first in a competitive fixture, on 9 October 2014; his header opened a 5–0 Wembley win over [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] in [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group E|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]].<ref name="England 5–0 San Marino">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 5–0 San Marino |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29454223 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 October 2014 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> Jagielka became the first Everton player to captain England when they played against Lithuania on 12 October 2015 in a UEFA Euro qualifying match.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-england-captaincy-short-story-10242155|title=Everton and the England captaincy: A short story|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|first=David|last=Prentice|date=12 October 2015|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
On 15 November 2016, he became the most capped Everton player by England when he came on as a second-half substitute against Spain in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|last=Beesley|first=Chris|title=Everton captain Jagielka breaks Alan Ball's record|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-captain-jagielka-breaks-alan-12182878|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|date=16 November 2016|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Jagielka is of Polish and Scottish descent.<ref name=guardian070512>{{cite news |title=England the next step for Jagielka |first=Louise |last=Taylor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/may/12/newsstory.sheffieldunited |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=12 May 2007 |accessdate=8 February 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Phil: Spain pain made me a man |first=Phil |last=Thomas |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/3168466/Spain-pain-made-Phil-Jagielka-a-man.html |newspaper=The Sun |location=London |date=7 October 2010 |accessdate= 8 August 2010}}</ref> His older brother [[Stephen Jagielka]] was also a professional midfielder, mainly for [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]]. Although he was loaned to Sheffield United for one season, the pair never featured together in a competitive fixture.<ref>{{cite news|title=Seasonal joy for Jagielkas|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/accrington_stanley/4556382.stm|accessdate=9 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Andrew|last=McKenzie|date=24 December 2005}}</ref> He also has two sisters, Barbara and Nicola.

(on loan from [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]) | clubnumber = 8 | youthyears1 = 2005–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[FC Porto|Porto]] | youthyears2 = 2008–2009 | youthclubs2 = Pasteleira | youthyears3 = 2009–2011 | youthclubs3 = [[Boavista F.C.|Boavista]] | youthyears4 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs4 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | years1 = 2012–2014 | clubs1 = [[S.L. Benfica B|Benfica B]] | caps1 = 17 | goals1 = 8 | years2 = 2012–2015 | clubs2 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | caps2 = 14 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2014–2015 | clubs3 = → [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (loan) | caps3 = 33 | goals3 = 4 | years4 = 2015–2016 | clubs4 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | caps4 = 30 | goals4 = 3 | years5 = 2016– | clubs5 = [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] | caps5 = 46 | goals5 = 3 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = → [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] (loan) | caps6 = 23 | goals6 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam2 = [[Portugal national under-18 football team|Portugal U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 6 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2011–2012 | nationalteam3 = [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 9 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | nationalyears4 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam4 = [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 14 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | nationalyears5 = 2013–2014 | nationalteam5 = [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal U21]] | nationalcaps5 = 6 | nationalgoals5 = 1 | nationalyears6 = 2014– | nationalteam6 = [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] | nationalcaps6 = 29 | nationalgoals6 = 0 | club-update = 10:58, 21 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 26 March 2018 | medaltemplates = {{medalCountry|{{fb|POR}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[UEFA European Championship]]}} {{medal|W|[[UEFA Euro 2016|2016 France]]|}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIFA Confederations Cup]]}} {{medal|3rd|[[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|2017 Russia]]|}} }} '''André Filipe Tavares Gomes''' ({{IPA-pt|ɐ̃ˈdɾɛ ˈɡomɨʃ}}; born 30 July 1993) is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]] for English club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], on loan from [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], and the [[Portugal national football team|Portugal national team]]. He played three years at [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]], where he won [[Treble (association football)|the domestic treble]] in the [[2013–14 S.L. Benfica season|2013–14 season]]. In July 2014 he joined [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] and, two years later, signed with [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] also in the Spanish [[La Liga]]. Gomes earned 37 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for Portugal all youth levels accounted for, including six for [[Portugal national under-21 football team|the under-21s]]. He represented the nation at [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]] – winning the tournament – and the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|2017 Confederations Cup]]. ==Club career== ===Benfica=== Born in [[Grijó (Vila Nova de Gaia)|Grijó]], [[Vila Nova de Gaia]], [[Porto District]], Gomes joined [[S.L. Benfica]]'s youth system at the age of 18, playing his last year as a junior with the [[Lisbon]] club. On 28 July 2012 he appeared in his first game with the first team, in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Gil Vicente F.C.|Gil Vicente]],{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/emdirecto/1a-liga/interior/em-diretonova-chapa-cinco-2692004.html|title=Nova chapa cinco|trans-title=Another fiver|newspaper=[[O Jogo]]|language=pt|date=28 July 2012|accessdate=4 August 2012}} and spent [[2012–13 Segunda Liga|his first season]] as a senior with [[S.L. Benfica B|the reserve side]], competing in the [[Segunda Liga|second division]]. Gomes scored his first goals with Benfica B in league matches against [[S.C. Braga B|Braga B]] (2–2 home draw){{cite news|url=http://www.record.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/2--liga/detalhe/benfica-b-sp-braga-b-2-2-andre-gomes-da-empate-nos-descontos-772861.html|title=Benfica B-Sp. Braga B, 2–2: André Gomes dá empate nos descontos|trans-title=Benfica B-Sp. Braga B, 2–2: André Gomes for the draw in injury time|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=pt|date=11 August 2012|accessdate=14 February 2014}} and [[C.F. Os Belenenses|Belenenses]] (6–0, also at home).{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/2--liga/detalhe/benfica-b-belenenses-goleada-na-luz-6-0-775375.html|title=Benfica B-Belenenses: Goleada na Luz (6–0)|trans-title=Benfica B-Belenenses: Routing at the Luz (6–0)|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=27 August 2012|accessdate=19 January 2016}} On 18 October 2012, he made his official debut with the main squad, playing 25 minutes after coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Eduardo Salvio]] and netting in a [[2012–13 Taça de Portugal|4–0 win]] at [[S.C. Freamunde|Freamunde]], for the [[Taça de Portugal]].{{cite web|url=http://portugoal.net/index.php/more-benfica-news/37338-taca-benfica-cruise-past-freamunde |title=Taça: Benfica cruise past Freamunde|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=18 October 2012|accessdate=19 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222015706/http://portugoal.net/index.php/more-benfica-news/37338-taca-benfica-cruise-past-freamunde|archivedate=22 February 2014|df=}} Gomes' momentum in Benfica's first team continued on 27 October 2012, as he started and scored in a 3–0 away win over Gil Vicente in his first [[Primeira Liga]] appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-benfica-news/37563-new-look-benfica-return-to-table-top|title=New-look Benfica return to table top|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=28 October 2012|accessdate=28 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222013703/http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-benfica-news/37563-new-look-benfica-return-to-table-top|archivedate=22 February 2014|df=}} He continued, however, to be mainly associated with the B-team. On 31 January 2014, Benfica (and [[Benfica Stars Fund]]) sold 100% of Gomes' economic rights to a private company, Meriton Capital Limited, for €15 million, plus 25% of a future transfer fee.{{cite web|url=http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/fsd29830.pdf|title=Comunicado|trans-title=Announcement|publisher=[[Portuguese Securities Market Commission]]|language=pt|date=3 April 2014|accessdate=5 September 2014}} He remained at the [[Estádio da Luz]] until the end of [[2013–14 S.L. Benfica season|the campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://www.soccernews.com/benfica-cash-rodrigo-andre-gomes/137317/|title=Benfica cash in on Rodrigo, Andre Gomes|publisher=Soccer News|last=Lazarevic|first=Nemanja|date=1 February 2014|accessdate=9 February 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/peter-lim-benfica-andre-gomes-rodrigo/52ec4a94e4b0cbb7a075f5d0.html|title=Peter Lim, o homem que comprou os passes de Rodrigo e André Gomes|trans-title=Peter Lim, the men who bought the rights for Rodrigo and André Gomes|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=1 February 2014|accessdate=19 August 2014}} On 16 April 2014, Gomes played the full 90 minutes in the second leg of the semi-finals of the [[2013–14 Taça de Portugal|Portuguese Cup]], scoring the final 3–1 after a brilliant individual effort to help his team – who played with one man less for 60 minutes against [[FC Porto|Porto]] – win the tie 3–2 on aggregate.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2606506/Benfica-3-1-Porto-agg-3-2-Match-report-Andre-Gomes-books-Eagles-Portuguese-Cup-final-place-Jorge-Jesus-Ricardo-Quaresma-red-fans-invade-pitch-stormy-clash.html|title=Benfica 3–1 Porto (agg 3–2): Andre Gomes books Eagles' Portuguese Cup final place as Jorge Jesus and Ricardo Quaresma see red and fans invade pitch in stormy clash|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Homewood|first=Brian|date=16 April 2014|access-date=4 June 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2014/04/17/futbol/futbol_internacional/1397687122.html|title=El Benfica remonta y pasa a la final de Copa|trans-title=Benfica come back from behind and reach Cup final|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=es|date=17 April 2014|accessdate=17 April 2014}} He ended [[2013–14 Primeira Liga|the season]] with 23 games all competitions comprised, helping the club win the first [[Treble (association football)|treble]] in its history (league, cup and [[2013–14 Taça da Liga|Taça da Liga]]). ===Valencia=== On 17 July 2014, Gomes agreed to a one-season loan deal with [[Valencia CF|Valencia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.valenciacf.com/ver/36381/comunicado-oficial-del-valencia-cf.html|title=Comunicado oficial|trans-title=Official announcement|publisher=Valencia CF|language=es|date=17 July 2014|accessdate=19 July 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Internacional/espanha/interior.aspx?content_id=895137|title=Valencia regista André Gomes como emprestado pelo Benfica|trans-title=Valencia register André Gomes as loaned by Benfica|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=17 July 2014|accessdate=19 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720002942/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Internacional/espanha/interior.aspx?content_id=895137|archivedate=20 July 2014|df=dmy-all}} joining a host of compatriots including manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]]. Although his economic rights were owned by [[Peter Lim]], a loan deal was arranged to take him and [[Rodrigo (footballer, born 1991)|Rodrigo]] to the Spanish club due to Lim's purchase of the latter.{{cite web|url=https://rr.sapo.pt/bolabranca_detalhe.aspx?fid=47&did=155784|title=Valência procura "forma jurídica" para levar Rodrigo e André Gomes|trans-title=Valencia look for "legal way" to take Rodrigo and André Gomes|publisher=[[Rádio Renascença]]|language=pt|date=15 July 2014|accessdate=19 August 2014}} Gomes made his [[La Liga]] debut on 23 August 2014, starting in a 1–1 away draw against [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/primera/jornada_1/sev_val/|title=Punto de fe del Valencia|trans-title=Valencia point of faith|newspaper=Marca|last=Campos|first=Tomás|location=Madrid|language=es|date=23 August 2014|accessdate=3 September 2014}} He scored his first goal in the competition on 22 September, netting the second of a 3–0 away win over [[Getafe CF|Getafe]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/primera/jornada_4/get_val/|title=El naranja pinta muy bien|trans-title=Orange is such a great colour|newspaper=Marca|last=Melero|first=Delfín|location=Madrid|language=es|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=19 January 2016}} On 12 June 2015, Benfica and Valencia announced they had reached an agreement on Gomes' federative rights. Subsequently, he signed a contract with the Spaniards until 30 June 2020.{{cite web|url=http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi/emitentes/docs/FR56142.pdf|title=Comunicado|trans-title=Announcement|publisher=Portuguese Securities Market Commission|language=pt|date=12 June 2015|access-date=12 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/41501/comunicado-oficial---andre-gomes.html|title=André Gomes joins Valencia CF on a permanent deal through to 2020|publisher=Valencia CF|date=12 June 2015|access-date=12 June 2015}} ===Barcelona=== On 21 July 2016, [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] announced they had reached an agreement with Valencia for the transfer of Gomes,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36862314|title=Andre Gomes: Barcelona agree deal to sign Valencia midfielder|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=21 July 2016|access-date=21 July 2016}} for a fee of €35 million, plus €20 million in add-ons.{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/barcelona-sign-andre-gomes-valencia-8473083|title=Barcelona to sign Andre Gomes from Valencia after 'agreeing €55million deal' for Portugal midfielder|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|last=Corless|first=Liam|date=21 July 2016|access-date=24 July 2016}} He made his competitive debut on 17 August, playing the full 90 minutes in a [[2016 Supercopa de España|3–0 home win]] against Sevilla for the [[Supercopa de España]] and being directly involved in two of the goals.{{cite news|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/barcelona-3-0-sevilla-5-0-agg-arda-turan-and-leo-messi-seal-super-cup-win-5330613|title=Barcelona 3–0 Sevilla (5–0 agg): Arda Turan and Leo Messi seal Super Cup win|newspaper=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|last=Sharma|first=Rik|date=18 August 2016|access-date=18 August 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sport.es/es/noticias/barca/andre-gomes-marcaje-5330468|title=André Gomes se 'disfrazó' de Iniesta participando en dos goles|trans-title=André Gomes 'disguised' as Iniesta by taking part in two goals|newspaper=Sport|last=López|first=Ricard|language=es|date=18 August 2016|access-date=18 August 2016}} Gomes scored his first goal for the team on 19 March 2017, closing a 4–2 home win against his former club Valencia.{{cite news|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/andre-gomes-scores-his-first-goal-for-barcelona-against-his-former-club-5910749|title=Andre Gomes scores his first goal for Barcelona... against his former club|newspaper=Sport|date=19 March 2017|access-date=22 March 2017}} He was voted the worst signing of [[2016–17 La Liga|the season]] by readers of ''[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/futbol/primera-division/2017/05/24/59257eeae2704e78028b45da.html|title=Messi se cuela en LaLiga más blanca|trans-title=Messi sneaks into the whitest LaLiga|newspaper=Marca|last=Roca|first=Álvaro|location=Madrid|language=es|date=25 May 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}} In [[2017 Copa del Rey Final|the final]] of the [[Copa del Rey]], however, he replaced injured [[Javier Mascherano]] early into the first half of the match against [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]], playing mostly as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]] and providing the [[Assist (football)|assist]] for [[Neymar]] who netted the second in an eventual [[2016–17 Copa del Rey|3–1 triumph]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39909498|title=Barcelona 3–1 Alavés|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 May 2017|accessdate=28 May 2017}} On 9 August 2018, and even though he was nursing a leg injury sustained during pre-season,{{cite web|url=https://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/futebol-internacional/futebol-espanhol/noticia/andre-gomes-desfalcara-o-barcelona-por-dois-meses-diz-radio.ghtml|title=André Gomes desfalcará o Barcelona por dois meses, diz rádio|trans-title=Barcelona to make do without André Gomes for two months, says radio|publisher=[[Rede Globo|Globo Esporte]]|language=pt|date=29 July 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}} ===Everton=== Gomes moved to English club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a [[2018–19 Premier League|season]]-long loan for a fee of €2.25 million.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2018-2019/agreement-with-everton-for-the-loan-of-andre-gomes-fcbarcelona|title=Agreement with Everton for the loan of André Gomes|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}} He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 21 October, playing 82 minutes in a 2–0 home win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45853586|title=Everton 2–0 Crystal Palace|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|date=21 October 2018|accessdate=7 November 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/andre-gomes-everton-debut-impressive-15315463|title=Why Andre Gomes' Everton debut was so impressive as Marco Silva's attacking gamble pays off|newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]]|last=Jones|first=Adam|date=21 October 2018|accessdate=25 November 2018}} He scored his first goal for the club on 2 February 2019, in a 1–3 home defeat to [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47011463|title=Everton 1–3 Wolverhampton Wanderers|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Johnston|first=Neil|date=2 February 2019|accessdate=8 March 2019}} ==International career== [[File:Russia-Portugal CC2017 (5).jpg|thumb|Gomes playing against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] at the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]]] Gomes represented [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal]] at the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/seleccao/edgar-borges-convocatoria-portugal-europeu-sub-19/1354495-1194.html|title=Euro de sub-19: Sporting e Benfica em maioria nos convocados|trans-title=Under-19 Euro: Sporting and Benfica dominate squad|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=11 June 2012|accessdate=4 August 2012}} At the age of 19 he received his first call-up to [[Portugal national football team|the senior team]], for a friendly against [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]] on 6 February 2013,{{cite news|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=380552|title="Jesus tem-me ensinado muita coisa" – André Gomes|trans-title="Jesus has taught me many things" – André Gomes|newspaper=[[A Bola]]|language=pt|date=4 February 2013|accessdate=4 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208011834/http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=380552|archive-date=8 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} but remained unused in the 2–3 home loss.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/friendlies/season=2014/matches/round=2000374/match=2011317/postmatch/report/|title=Portugal succumb at home to Ecuador|publisher=UEFA|date=6 February 2013|accessdate=8 October 2015}} Gomes made his full debut on 7 September 2014, starting and playing the full 90 minutes in a 0–1 loss to [[Albania national football team|Albania]] at the [[Estádio Municipal de Aveiro]] for the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualification|qualifiers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/portugal-vs-albania/1653150/report|title=Portugal 0–1 Albania: Seleccao stunned by Balaj beauty|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|last=Balaj|first=Bekim|date=7 September 2014|accessdate=7 September 2014}} He was selected for the squad that appeared in the finals in France,{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/portugal/story/2874983/new-bayern-munich-signing-renato-sanches-picked-for-portugal-squad|title=Portugal name Bayern Munich signing Renato Sanches for Euros squad|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=14 June 2016}} starting in their first game, a 1–1 draw to [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] in [[Saint-Étienne]] where he provided the [[Assist (football)|assist]] to [[Nani]]'s goal before being replaced by [[Eder (Portuguese footballer)|Eder]] late into the second half.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000448/match=2017959/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Ice-cool Iceland claim Portugal point|publisher=UEFA|last=Burke|first=Chris|date=14 June 2016|accessdate=14 June 2016}} Gomes also represented Portugal at the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]] in [[Russia]],{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/internacional/selecao/noticias/interior/direto--os-convocados-de-portugal-para-a-taca-das-confederacoes-8506152.html|title=Éder fica fora dos convocados, Beto e José Sá nas escolhas|trans-title=Éder out of squad, Beto and José Sá picked|newspaper=O Jogo|language=pt|date=25 May 2017|accessdate=18 September 2017}} playing four times as they finished in third place.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/matches/round=274643/match=300334886/match-report.html#nosticky|title=Portugal come from behind to finish third|publisher=FIFA|date=2 July 2017|accessdate=15 September 2017}} He was included in a preliminary 35-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]],{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb|title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad – 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced?|publisher=Goal|date=17 May 2018|accessdate=17 May 2018}} but did not make the final cut.{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/portugal-world-cup-squad|title=Nearly half Portugal's Euro squad to miss World Cup|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=17 May 2018|accessdate=17 May 2018}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 17 March 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/andre-gomes/245897/|title=André Gomes|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=27
