{{About|the footballer born in 1982|the footballer born in 1972|Maarten Stekelenburg (footballer, born 1972)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Maarten Stekelenburg | image = Stekelenburg Audi quattro-Cup 44.JPG | image_size = 200 | caption = Stekelenburg with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2015 | alt = | fullname = Maarten Stekelenburg<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|9|22|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |title=FIFA World Cup South Africa 2010: List of players: Netherlands |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/22/85/78/fwc_2010_squadlists.pdf |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=20 |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Haarlem]], Netherlands | height = 1.98 m<ref>{{cite web |title=Player profile: Maarten Stekelenburg |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/players/m/ms/maarten-stekelenburg |publisher=Everton F.C. |accessdate=14 December 2018}}</ref> | currentclub = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | clubnumber = 22 | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | youthyears1 = | youthyears2 = | youthyears3 = 1997–2002 | youthclubs1 = Zandvoort '75 | youthclubs2 = Schoten | youthclubs3 = [[Ajax Youth Academy|Ajax]] | years1 = 2002–2011 |clubs1 = [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] | caps1 = 191 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2011–2013 |clubs2 = [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] | caps2 = 48 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2013–2016 |clubs3 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps3 = 19 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2014–2015 |clubs4 = → [[AS Monaco|Monaco]] (loan) | caps4 = 1 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2015–2016 |clubs5 = → [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] (loan) | caps5 = 17 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2016– |clubs6 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | caps6 = 19 | goals6 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2002–2003 | nationalteam1 = [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2004– | nationalteam2 = [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] | nationalcaps2 = 58 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{NED}}}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[association football|football]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|RU|[[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 South Africa]]|[[Netherlands national football team|Team]]}} | club-update = 17:04, 1 July 2017 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:04, 1 July 2017 (UTC) }} '''Maarten Stekelenburg''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈmaːrtə(n) ˈsteːkələ(n)ˌbɵrx}}; born 22 September 1982) is a Dutch [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands national team]].
Stekelenburg began his career at [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]], playing 282 matches over nine seasons and winning nine honours, including two [[Eredivisie]] titles. He went on to play for [[A.S. Roma|Roma]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and Everton.
Stekelenburg made his debut for the Netherlands in 2004, and has earned 58 caps in total as of July 2018. He was understudy to [[Edwin van der Sar]] at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2008]], then was first choice as he helped his nation to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final|final]] and played at [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]].
==Club career== ===Ajax=== Stekelenburg began his career at Zandvoort '75 before joining VV Schoten, which he left for [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] when he was 15 years old. He made his official debut for Ajax on 24 February 2002, in a match against [[NAC Breda]]. At the start of the 2002–03 season, he won his first prize when Ajax won the [[Johan Cruyff Shield]]. In 2004, he and Ajax won the [[Eredivisie]] championship, having played ten matches that season.
Stekelenburg became the first choice goalkeeper at Ajax in the 2005–06 season. In 2006, he won his first [[KNVB Cup]]. At the start of the 2006–07 season, he won his second Johan Cruyff Shield, which he helped his team defend the next season, and later on in 2006–07, he won his second KNVB Cup.
[[File:Ebecilio Stekelenburg Van der Wiel.jpg|thumb|Stekelenburg with his Ajax teammates]]
Stekelenburg was named Ajax "Player of the Year" for the [[2007–08 Eredivisie|2007–08 season]], succeeding [[Wesley Sneijder]]. During the [[2008–09 Eredivisie|2008–09 season]], he lost his place in the goal to [[Kenneth Vermeer]] due to injuries. He re-established himself as the first-choice goalkeeper under new manager [[Martin Jol]] and subsequently had a very strong season for both Ajax and the Dutch national side. During the 2009–10 season, Stekelenburg went on to have a consistent season, playing in all of Ajax's Eredivisie and Europa League matches, the latter after they were eliminated from the [[UEFA Champions League]] in the group stage. However, Stekelenburg sustained a finger injury which kept him out for the remainder of the season. He made a total of 51 appearances in the 2010–11 season in all competitions.
After winning the [[2010–11 Eredivisie]] on 15 May 2011, Stekelenburg dropped the trophy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sqrrzWN8WKQ|title=Ajax kampioen: Maarten Stekelenburg laat de schaal vallen!!|publisher=YouTube|date=15 May 2011|accessdate=30 December 2017|language=nl}}</ref> while standing on top of the Ajax team coach with [[Jan Vertonghen]]. He won Ajax Player of the Year for the second time.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11854_7055164,00.html |title= Roma told to up Stekelenburg bid |publisher= Sky Sports |date= 22 July 2011 |accessdate= 21 August 2011}}</ref>
===Roma=== On 1 August 2011, it was announced Stekelenburg had officially transferred to [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] for €6.325 million transfer fee plus bonuses, making him the first Dutch footballer to ever play for the Italian club.<ref name="Stekelenburg naar AS Roma">{{cite web|title=Definitief: Stekelenburg naar AS Roma | Ajax1.nl | De site met het laatste Ajax nieuws, foto's, Video's, Columns, Twitter, Hyve|url=http://ajax1.nl/archief/definitief-stekelenburg-naar-roma/|publisher=Ajax1.nl|accessdate=1 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://res.cloudinary.com/as-roma-turbine-sandbox/image/upload/v1447693974/asroma-uat/hvnwyxqo1gdbhnj1mw2w.pdf|title=Acquisizione A Titolo Definitivo Dei Diritti Alle Prestazioni Sportive Del Calciatore Maarten Stekelenburg|date=1 August 2011|access-date=2 July 2017|publisher=A.S. Roma|language=Italian}}</ref> He picked the number 24 shirt, which is the day his son was born.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.football-italia.org/node/10180|title=Stekelenburg: 'Forza Roma!'|date=6 August 2011|accessdate=19 August 2011|work=Football Italia}}</ref> He made his debut on 11 September 2011, against [[Cagliari Calcio|Cagliari]].
===Fulham=== On 3 June 2013, Roma [[director of football|sporting director]] [[Franco Baldini]] confirmed he had finalised a deal with [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] for the sale of Stekelenburg.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11681/8755642/Transfer-news-Roma-confirm-Fulham-deal-for-Maarten-Stekelenburg |title=Transfer news: Roma confirm Fulham deal for Maarten Stekelenburg | publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 June 2013 |accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref> Two days later, on 5 June, Fulham announced Stekelenburg had signed on a four-year contract for an undisclosed transfer fee;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/june/05/stekelenburg|title=Stekelenburg Signs|publisher=Fulham FC|date=5 June 2013|accessdate=5 June 2013}}</ref> Roma later disclosed the fee was €5.6 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://res.cloudinary.com/as-roma-turbine-sandbox/image/upload/v1445281943/asroma-uat/lugmjrzb0usuepz0d0ew.pdf|title=Relazione Finanziaria Annuale Al 30 Giugno 2014|date=6 October 2014|access-date=28 July 2017|publisher=A.S. Roma|language=Italian|page=122|quote=Valore di Cessione}}</ref> He made his debut on 17 August in a 1–0 win away to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]; however, he came off injured in the second half and was replaced by [[David Stockdale]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23644878|title=Sunderland 0–1 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 August 2013|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> He returned on 21 October at a win against Crystal Palace, but went on to lose the next four starts in a row.
Following the sacking of [[René Meulensteen]] as Fulham manager, Stekelenburg was dropped to the bench in favour of Stockdale by [[Felix Magath]], and following Fulham's relegation and Stockdale's departure, lost his place in the squad altogether, as Magath favoured [[Jesse Joronen]] and [[Marcus Bettinelli]].
===Monaco=== On 9 August 2014, Stekelenburg joined French club [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web|author=@simonremoussin |url=http://www.asm-fc.com/en/article/maarten-stekelenburg-joins-as-monaco-on-loan-65465.html |title=Maarten Stekelenburg joins AS Monaco on loan | News | AS Monaco FC |website=Asm-fc.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030161059/http://www.asm-fc.com/en/article/maarten-stekelenburg-joins-as-monaco-on-loan-65465.html |archivedate=30 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> With [[Danijel Subašić]] as Monaco's starting goalkeeper, Stekelenburg was preferred for cup matches, making his debut in the round of 16 of the [[Coupe de la Ligue]] away to [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] on 17 December. After a 1–1 draw at the [[Stade de Gerland]], he helped Monaco win 5–4 in a [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] by saving from [[Jordan Ferri]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pitzus|first1=Alessandro|title=OL – ASM (1–1, 5 t.a.b. 4) : Au bout du suspense, Monaco a sorti Lyon|trans-title= OL – ASM (1–1, 5–4 on penalties): After suspense, Monaco put Lyon out on penalties|url=http://www.eurosport.fr/football/coupe-de-la-ligue/2014-2015/ol-asm-1-1-5-t.a.b.-4-au-bout-du-suspense-monaco-a-sorti-lyon_sto4516963/story.shtml|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=Eurosport|date=17 December 2014|language=French}}</ref> In the semi-finals on 4 February 2015 against [[SC Bastia|Bastia]] at the [[Stade Louis II]], it again went to penalties after a goalless draw. He saved from [[Guillaume Gillet]] and [[Giovanni Sio]], but Monaco were eliminated nonetheless.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coupe de la Ligue : Bastia rejoint le PSG en finale en éliminant Monaco aux tirs au but|trans-title=Coupe de la Ligue: Bastia join PSG in the final by eliminating Monaco on penalties|url=http://www.eurosport.fr/football/coupe-de-la-ligue/2014-2015/coupe-de-la-ligue-bastia-rejoint-le-psg-en-finale-en-eliminant-monaco-aux-tirs-au-but_sto4590327/story.shtml|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=Eurosport|language=French}}</ref> His sole [[Ligue 1]] appearance came on 22 March away to [[Stade de Reims|Reims]], a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bregevin|first1=Vincent|title=Ligue 1 – Reims – Monaco (1–3) : L'ASM s'impose à Reims et est dans la course au titre|trans-title=Ligue 1 – Reims – Monaco (1–3): ASM impose themselves on Reims and stay on course for the title|url=http://www.eurosport.fr/football/ligue-1/2014-2015/ligue-1-reims-monaco-1-3-l-asm-s-impose-a-reims-et-revient-a-un-point-du-podium_sto4650188/story.shtml|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=Eurosport|date=22 March 2015|language=French}}</ref> On 1 June, the club announced Stekelenburg would return to Fulham after his season-long loan expired.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asmonaco.com/en/article/berbatov-story-ending-at-as-monaco-68167.html|title=Berbatov : story ending at AS Monaco|publisher=AS Monaco FC|date=1 June 2015|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
===Southampton=== On 22 June 2015, [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] signed Stekelenburg on a season-long loan from Fulham.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Saints sign Dutch goalkeeper Stekelenburg |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/20150622-announcement-southampton-sign-maarten-stekelenburg-fulham-2502863.aspx |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=22 June 2015}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on 30 July in the [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|third qualifying round]] of [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|the season's Europa League]], a 3–0 win over [[SBV Vitesse|Vitesse]] at [[St Mary's Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Adam|title=Southampton 3–0 Vitesse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667103|accessdate=30 July 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 July 2015}}</ref> He made his Premier League debut for ''the Saints'' in a 2–2 draw away to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on the opening day of the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750572|title=Newcastle 2–2 Southampton match report|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref>
===Everton=== On 1 July 2016, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], managed by compatriot [[Ronald Koeman]], announced they had signed Stekelenburg from Fulham for an undisclosed transfer fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36690263|title=Maarten Stekelenburg: Everton sign goalkeeper from Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 July 2016|date=1 July 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 13 August as ''the Toffees'' began their campaign with a 1–1 home draw against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hart|first1=Simon|title=Everton vs Tottenham: Erik Lamela cancels out Ross Barkley opener as Maarten Stekelenburg denies Spurs|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/everton-vs-tottenham-erik-lamela-cancels-out-ross-barkley-opener-as-maartin-stekelenburg-denies-a7189206.html|accessdate=16 October 2016|work=The Independent|date=13 August 2016}}</ref> and on 15 October, he saved penalties from [[Kevin De Bruyne]] and [[Sergio Agüero]] to ensure the same result away to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|title=Maarten Stekelenburg saves two penalties as Nolito rescues City a point|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manchester-city-vs-everton-match-report-maarten-stekelenburg-nolito-romelu-lukaku-a7363461.html|accessdate=16 October 2016|work=The Independent|date=15 October 2016}}</ref> Stekelenburg was limped off the field after suffering from a leg injury in the 63rd minute of the [[Merseyside derby]] at Goodison Park against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 19 December 2016. Stekelenburg returned to action in April 2017, when Ronald Koeman dropped [[Joel Robles]] after 17-straight starts by the Spanish goalkeeper.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirkbride|first1=Phil|title=Everton boss Ronald Koeman explains decision to drop Joel Robles|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-boss-ronald-koeman-explains-12933595|accessdate=1 July 2017|work=Liverpool Echo|date=23 April 2017}}</ref>
==International career== ===Netherlands national football team=== Stekelenburg was a member of the Dutch squad at the [[2001 FIFA World Youth Championship]]. He made his international debut for the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] on 3 September 2004 against [[Liechtenstein national football team|Liechtenstein]], whom they beat 3–0.
====2006 World Cup and Euro 2008==== Stekelenburg was called up by manager [[Marco van Basten]] for the squad of the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in Germany, but he did not play any match during this tournament as [[Edwin van der Sar]] was first choice.
Despite his international debut in 2004, Stekelenburg was called-up to Van Basten's [[UEFA Euro 2008]] squad to play as understudy to Van der Sar. He participated in the Group C match against [[Romania national football team|Romania]] on 17 June—with the Netherlands already having qualified for the quarter-finals, the coach fielded a second-string side to give players like Stekelenburg an appearance. He kept a clean sheet in the 2–0 win at the [[Stade de Suisse]] in [[Bern]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=France 0–2 Italy & Netherlands 2–0 Romania|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2008/7363393.stm|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 June 2008}}</ref>
In a September 2008 friendly match against [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]], Stekelenburg was sent-off after 44 minutes of the first half for fouling [[Joshua Kennedy]], becoming the first goalkeeper of the Dutch national side to receive a red card.
====2010 World Cup and after==== [[File:Michael Krohn-Dehli - Maarten Stekelenburg 20120609.jpg|thumb|Stekelenburg beaten by [[Michael Krohn-Dehli]] at Euro 2012]]
After Van der Sar's retirement from the national team, Stekelenburg became the Netherlands' first-choice goalkeeper under manager [[Bert van Marwijk]]. Stekelenburg was included in the preliminary squad for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iO9bETRJh0iovmmUN7ZeFDugTEIg |title=Van Marwijk trims Dutch squad to 27 | publisher=AFP|date=15 May 2010 |accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref> On 27 May 2010, Van Marwijk announced he would be part of the final 23-man squad participating in the competition.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/27/holland-world-cup-23-man-squad |title=Holland coach Bert van Marwijk finalises World Cup squad |newspaper=The Guardian |date=27 May 2010 |agency=Press Association |accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref> Stekelenburg helped the Netherlands reach [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final|the final of the competition]] against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] by making key saves throughout the tournament, from [[Kaká]] in the Netherlands' 2–1 victory against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in the quarter-finals.<ref name=reuters/> He conceded six goals in the whole tournament, two of them being [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]]s. Despite making a number of saves in the final, he ended up on the losing side, conceding the match's only goal to [[Andrés Iniesta]] in the 116th minute.
Stekelenburg played all three matches during the group stages of [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]] as the Netherlands finished bottom of [[UEFA Euro 2012 Group B|their group]].
On 7 October 2016, four years after his last international appearance, Stekelenburg started in a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group A|2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]] match against [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]], a 4–1 Dutch victory.

10:01, 30 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Séamus Coleman''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|eɪ|m|ə|s|_|ˈ|k|oʊ|l|m|ən}} (born 11 October 1988) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right-back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]].
Originally a [[Gaelic football]]er, Coleman started his association football career with amateur club St Catherine's in Killybegs. He joined [[League of Ireland Premier Division|League of Ireland]] side [[Sligo Rovers F.C.|Sligo Rovers]] in 2006 after impressing in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against them. He then made the move to England to sign for Everton in January 2009 for a £60,000 fee. In 2010, he spent half a season on loan with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]], helping them win promotion via the [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final|Championship play-offs]], before returning to Everton where he has made over 200 appearances, and has been regarded as one of the league's top full-backs.
Coleman has been a senior international for the Republic of Ireland since 2011, acquiring over 40 caps. He won the [[2011 Nations Cup]] and was awarded the [[FAI International Football Awards#Under 21 International Player of the Year|FAI Under-21 International Player of the Year]] in both 2009 and 2010. He was selected for the Ireland squad at [[UEFA Euro 2016]], [[Captain (association football)|captaining]] Ireland against both [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[France national football team|France]]. He was named the new Ireland captain in September 2016 following [[Robbie Keane]]'s international retirement.
==Club career==
===Sligo Rovers=== Coleman was born in the fishing port of [[Killybegs]],<ref name="http://www.thescore.ie">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-gaa-968638-Jun2013/|title=If Seamus Coleman played GAA, he'd be a star with Donegal – McGuinness|website=The42|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|first=Sean|last=Farrell|date=11 January 2013|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref> in the Irish county of [[Donegal]].<ref name="Hugman2010-11 89"/> Originally a [[Gaelic football]]er who, aged 16, played as a back on his local [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] team [[C.L.G. Na gCealla Beaga|Na Cealla Beaga]],<ref name=defy_logic_injury-hit_shock_title_success>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/gaelic-football/boyle-looks-to-defy-logic-and-inspire-injuryhit-killybegs-to-shock-title-success-26686159.html|title=Boyle looks to defy logic and inspire injury-hit Killybegs to shock title success|work=[[Irish Independent]]|first=Donnchadh|last=Boyle|date=2 October 2010|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Guardianprofile">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/oct/28/everton-seamus-coleman-gaelic-football|title=Everton's Seamus Coleman uses Gaelic roots to grow in English football|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Andy|last=Hunter|date=28 October 2011|accessdate=28 October 2011|location=London}}</ref> Coleman was spotted by [[Sligo Rovers F.C.|Sligo Rovers]] when he lined up against them in a friendly for his hometown club, St Catherine's.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joe.ie/index.php/uncategorized/nivea-player-profile-seamus-coleman/344515|title=Nivea Player Profile: Seamus Coleman|publisher=JOE.ie|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He made his [[League of Ireland]] debut against [[Derry City F.C|Derry City]] at the [[Brandywell Stadium|Brandywell]] in October 2006 as a substitute for [[Adam Hughes (footballer)|Adam Hughes]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/coleman-over-the-moon-as-toffees-extend-his-contract-28953174.html|title=Coleman 'over the moon' as Toffees extend his contract|work=Irish Independent|first=Daniel|last=McDonnell|date=1 January 2013|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Sligo Rovers coach [[Rob McDonald]] did not rate Coleman very highly as a player, telling him that he should join [[League of Ireland First Division]] club [[Finn Harps F.C.|Finn Harps]].<ref name="Hannigan">{{cite news|last=Hannigan|first=Mary|title=No drama and no sulking for Coleman – just dreams of Brazil|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/no-drama-and-no-sulking-for-coleman-just-dreams-of-brazil-1.1517900|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=10 September 2013|date=6 September 2013}}</ref> McDonald departed Sligo Rovers in March 2007,<ref>{{cite news|last=Finn|first=Stephen|title=McDonald departure leaves Sligo behind eight-ball|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/mcdonald-departure-leaves-sligo-behind-eightball-26269136.html|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=10 September 2013|date=6 March 2007}}</ref> and was replaced by [[Paul Cook (footballer)|Paul Cook]], of whom Coleman later said: "He made me feel like I was the best player in the League. It just makes such a difference when you have a manager who believes in you".<ref name="Hannigan"/>
Coleman was [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)#Red card (dismissal)|sent off]] on 28 September 2007 in a 3–0 loss at [[Bohemian F.C.|Bohemians]], for a two-footed challenge on their substitute John-Paul Kelly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Red card swings game in Bohs favour|url=http://www.irishfootballonline.com/news/7363.html|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=Irish Football Online|date=29 September 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009153516/http://www.irishfootballonline.com/news/7363.html|archivedate=9 October 2007}}</ref> He scored his only goal for Rovers against [[Bray Wanderers F.C.|Bray Wanderers]] on 17 May 2008, concluding a 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/irish/2008/0517/231981-sligo_bray1/|title=Sligo Rovers 3–0 Bray Wanderers|date=17 May 2008|publisher=[[RTÉ Sport]]|accessdate=5 January 2010}}</ref>
===Everton=== Following a recommendation by [[Willie McStay (footballer, born 1961)|Willie McStay]] to former teammate and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] manager [[David Moyes]], Coleman was signed by the [[Merseyside]] club for £60,000<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/good-deal-everton-fcs-seamus-3385779|title=We got good deal for Everton FC's Seamus Coleman says Sligo Rovers boss Paul Cook|work=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=21 January 2011|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> in January 2009, ahead of other interest from [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/everton-to-sign-seamus-coleman-1661881|title=Everton to sign Seamus Coleman|work=Sunday People|date=18 January 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> Before playing a game for Everton, Coleman had to undergo surgery on a career-threatening infected blister.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/683662/new-blow-as-evertons-james-vaughan-undergoes-surgery|title=New blow as James Vaughan undergoes surgery|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=7 October 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> He made his debut on 22 October 2009 in the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] group stage in a 5–0 loss to [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] at the [[Estádio da Luz]], being beaten to the ball by [[Javier Saviola]] for the first goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/8318447.stm|title=Benfica 5–0 Everton|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|first=Oliver|last=Brett|date=22 October 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> Three days later in his [[Goodison Park]] debut, a [[Premier League]] match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], Coleman was named [[Man of the Match]] after coming on as a first-half substitute for the injured [[Joseph Yobo]], and played an instrumental part for both of Everton's goals in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/06/premier-league-everton-tottenham-hotspur|title=Tim Howard's injury-time penalty save caps gallant Everton fightback|last=Hunter|first=Andy|date=6 December 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=6 December 2009|location=London}}</ref> He made his [[FA Cup]] debut against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] in the third round on 2 January 2010, replacing [[Tony Hibbert]] in the 80th minute and creating a goal for [[Tim Cahill]] two minutes later, in a 3–1 home win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/match/report/0910/everton-v-carlisle.html|title=Everton v Carlisle: Match Report|publisher=Everton F.C.|date=2 January 2010|accessdate=7 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103104950/http://www.evertonfc.com/match/report/0910/everton-v-carlisle.html|archivedate=3 January 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Seamus Coleman 2010.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Coleman celebrating promotion with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in 2010]]
====Loan to Blackpool==== On 19 March 2010, Coleman joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan, initially for one month as a replacement for the injured [[Neal Eardley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/blackpool/8576974.stm|title=Blackpool sign Everton full-back Seamus Coleman on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 March 2010|accessdate=24 March 2010}}</ref> He made his debut the next day, in a 2–2 draw at home to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1259428/Blackpool-2-Crystal-Palace-2-Eagles-denied-precious-victory-late-Burgess-strike.html|title=Blackpool 2 Crystal Palace 2: Eagles denied precious victory by late Burgess strike|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=20 March 2010|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the ''Tangerines'' in a 4–2 win away to [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] on 2 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1263130/Scunthorpe-2-Blackpool-4-DJ-Campbell-double-Ian-Holloways-troops.html|title=Scunthorpe 2 Blackpool 4: DJ Campbell at the double as Ian Holloway's troops march towards the play-offs|first=Alan|last=Biggs|work=Daily Mail|date=2 April 2010|accessdate=6 April 2010|location=London}}</ref> Later that month, Coleman's loan was extended until the end of the season,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11728/6094501/coleman-sticks-with-blackpool|title=Coleman sticks with Blackpool|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=15 April 2010}}</ref> while on 19 May he agreed a new four-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/e/everton/8692668.stm|title=Defender Seamus Coleman signs new deal at Everton|date=19 May 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> He played in Blackpool's [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final|play–off final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]], which they won 3–2 against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref name="Blackpool 3-2 Cardiff City">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8692465.stm|title=Blackpool 3–2 Cardiff City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Paul|last=Fletcher|date=22 May 2010|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref>
====Return from loan==== Coleman returned to Everton for the following season, breaking into the first team on the right of midfield. He scored his first goal for Everton against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third round on 21 September 2010. He opened the scoring at [[Griffin Park]] in the sixth minute, but also gave away a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] with a foul on [[Myles Weston]], which [[Ján Mucha]] saved from [[Charlie MacDonald]], although Brentford eventually won in a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] after a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brentford 1–1 Everton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/9009797.stm|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 September 2010}}</ref> He scored his first Premier League goal against his former team Blackpool on 6 November to secure a 2–2 draw at [[Bloomfield Road]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9149903.stm|title=Blackpool 2–2 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Mark|last=Ashenden|date=6 November 2010|accessdate=10 January 2011}}</ref> signed a new four-and-a-half-year deal two months later,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2011/01/20/blues-secure-double-contract-boost|title=Duo sign new deals|publisher=Everton F.C.|first=Matthew|last=Gamble|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=20 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121193630/http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2011/01/20/blues-secure-double-contract-boost|archivedate=21 January 2011}}</ref> and was nominated for the 2011 [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/apr/08/pfa-player-year-award-gareth-bale|title=PFA Player of the Year award nominees include Tottenham's Gareth Bale|work=The Guardian|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He finished the season having scored four league goals, though was sent off in the final game of the season, a 1–0 win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2012/11/18/everton-back-coleman-after-star-gets-vile-twitter-abuse/|title=Everton back Coleman after star gets vile Twitter abuse|work=Donegal Daily|date=18 November 2012|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2011/05/23/2500154/evertons-phil-jagielka-backs-seamus-coleman-to-shine-next-season|title=Everton's Phil Jagielka backs Seamus Coleman to shine next season after red card against Chelsea|publisher=Goal.com|first=Mark|last=Fordham|date=23 May 2011|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref>
On 31 December 2012, Coleman signed a new five-and-a-half-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20875146|title=Seamus Coleman signs new Everton deal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 December 2012|accessdate=31 December 2012}}</ref>
====2013–present==== [[File:1 seamus coleman 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|Coleman in action for Everton in 2015]]
The [[2013–14 Everton F.C. season|2013–14 season]] proved to be Coleman's best to date as he scored six league goals, more than his previous seasons at the club combined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1910773-everton-vs-queens-park-rangers-6-things-we-learned|title=6 Things We Learned From Everton VS Queens Park Rangers|publisher=Bleacher Report|first=Matt|last=Cheetham|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/126363/everton-vs-qpr/report?|title=Everton 4–0 QPR: Barkley, Jelavic & Coleman fire Toffees through|publisher=Goal.com|first=Tom J.|last=Doyle|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> In April, he was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=PFATOTY1314>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27180793 |title=Luis Suarez: Liverpool striker wins PFA Player of the Year award |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> He was also named Everton's Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year.<ref name=MartinezPraise>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/history/coleman-is-player-of-the-season|title=Coleman Is Player of the Season|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=5 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508174802/http://www.evertonfc.com/history/coleman-is-player-of-the-season|archivedate=8 May 2014}}</ref> Manager [[Roberto Martínez]] hailed Coleman as one of the best full-backs in world football as he was part of a defence which conceded just 39 goals to help Everton finish fifth with a club record of 72 Premier League points.<ref name=MartinezPraise/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/premier-league-table/2013|title=Barclays Premier League 2013/14|publisher=Sky Sports|date=23 May 2014|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He created 45 chances during the season, the third highest amongst Everton players and had the second highest pass completion at 88%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/squawka-awards-a-statistical-review-of-evertons-season/111807|title=Squawka Awards: A statistical review of Everton’s Premier League season|publisher=Squawka|first=Omar|last=Hamouda|date=19 May 2014|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref>
On 26 June 2014, Coleman signed a new five-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/26/seamus-coleman-everton-new-contract|title=Seamus Coleman signs new five-year contract with Everton|work=The Guardian|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> He scored his first ever goal in [[UEFA competitions|European football]] for Everton on 18 September 2014, netting their second in a 4–1 win over [[VfL Wolfsburg|Wolfsburg]] in the first match of their [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/29240782|title=Everton 4–1 VfL Wolfsburg|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Gary|last=Rose|date=18 September 2014|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> On 19 February 2015, he was again on target in Europe, in a 4–1 win over [[BSC Young Boys]] in the last 32.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31523676|title=BSC Young Boys 1–4 Everton|first=Mike|last=Whalley|date=19 February 2015|accessdate=21 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 22 March, Coleman scored the first goal in an eventual 2–1 away success against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] with ''Toffees'' boss Roberto Martínez praising the full-back for his performance, describing him as "magnificent in his defensive duties" and labelling his opener as "a striker's goal".<ref name="Martinez hails Coleman">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/soccer/roberto-martinez-hails-seamus-coleman-as-everton-beat-qpr-319920.html|title=Roberto Martinez hails Seamus Coleman as Everton beat QPR|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|first=Declan|last=Taylor|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
Coleman scored his only goal of the [[2015–16 Everton F.C. season|2015–16 season]] in a 3–0 away victory against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 6 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35447704|title=Stoke City 0–3 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Mandeep|last=Sanghera|date=6 February 2016|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
On 17 September, he opened his [[2016–17 Everton F.C. season|2016–17]] goalscoring account in a 3–1 home win against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] with a great solo run and finish on his weaker foot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/seamus-colemans-scores-fantastic-solo-goal-as-everton-put-boro-to-the-sword-35057215.html|title=Seamus Coleman's scores fantastic solo goal as Everton put Boro to the sword|work=Irish Independent|first=Carl|last=Markham|date=17 September 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He scored his second goal of the season on 19 November with an 89th-minute header to equalise in a 1–1 home draw against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37959842|title=Everton 1–1 Swansea City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Matt|last=Davis|date=19 November 2016|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> His first goal of 2017 came on 21 January as he secured all three points with an 87th-minute winner in a 1–0 triumph over Crystal Palace at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38620112|title=Crystal Palace 0–1 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Jamie|last=Strickland|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
Coleman suffered a fractured tibia and fibula in his right leg following a dangerous challenge from [[Neil Taylor (footballer)|Neil Taylor]] whilst on international duty with Ireland in March 2017 and was unlikely to return to action until 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-injury-update-2-3306449-Mar2017/|title=Seamus Coleman unlikely to return until 2018 after undergoing surgery|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Ryan|last=Bailey|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref> It was announced a few days after his injury that [[FIFA]] would pay his basic salary for the duration of his rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/fifa-to-pay-seamus-colemans-salary-during-rehab-3309172-Mar2017/|title=Fifa to pay Seamus Coleman's salary during rehab|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Paul|last=Fennessy|date=27 March 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>
Coleman made his Everton return on 31 January 2018, in a 2–1 win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref name = "Return">{{Cite news|title=Everton's Seamus Coleman to make Republic of Ireland return vs. Turkey|date=8 March 2018|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=PA Sport (Press Association)|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/republic-of-ireland/story/3411520/everton-seamus-coleman-to-make-republic-of-ireland-return-vs-turkey}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== Coleman has represented Ireland U18 schools, helping them retain the Centenary Shield in 2006. He is an [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Ireland under-21]] and under-23 international, having made his debut for the former against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerscene.ie/ss_gen/player.php?id=31&level=ss21|title=Seamus Coleman|publisher=Soccer Scene|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> On 10 August 2010, Coleman scored his first international goal in a 5–0 win against [[Estonia national under-21 football team|Estonia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101151&catid=3&Itemid=11|title=Ireland U21 put five past Estonia|publisher=[[Football Association of Ireland]]|date=10 August 2010|accessdate=19 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215203050/http://fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101151&catid=3&Itemid=11|archivedate=15 December 2010}}</ref> In the same month he won the 2009 FAI Under 21 Player of the Year Award.<ref name=FAI09>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101142:fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1:senior-men&Itemid=8 |title=FAI International Football Award winners announced |date=8 August 2010 |publisher=Football Association of Ireland |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823092537/http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101142%3Afai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1%3Asenior-men&Itemid=8 |archivedate=23 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He retained the award in 2010.<ref name=FAI10>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101529:21st-3fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1:senior-men&Itemid=8 |title=21st 3/FAI International Football Award winners announced |publisher=Football Association of Ireland |accessdate=7 February 2011 |date=7 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106022019/http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101529%3A21st-3fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1%3Asenior-men&Itemid=8 |archivedate=6 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He captained Ireland in a 1–0 defeat against [[Turkey national under-21 football team|Turkey]] in November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101234&catid=3&Itemid=11|title=U21s fall to late winner in Turkey|publisher=Football Association of Ireland|date=7 September 2010|accessdate=19 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911213528/http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101234&catid=3&Itemid=11|archivedate=11 September 2010}}</ref>
===Senior=== [[File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs Ireland 2013-09-10 - Seamus Coleman 05.JPG|thumb|upright|250px|Coleman playing for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in 2013]]
Coleman received his first call-up to the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|senior squad]] in October 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/1001/ireland_colemans.html|title=Seamus Coleman named in Trap's squad|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=1 October 2010|accessdate=13 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002121025/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/1001/ireland_colemans.html|archivedate=2 October 2010}}</ref> and made his full international debut in the Republic of Ireland's inaugural [[2011 Nations Cup|Nations Cup]] match against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] on 8 February 2011, which Ireland won 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0208/ireland_wales_carlingnationscup.html|title=Republic of Ireland 3–0 Wales|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=8 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211022530/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0208/ireland_wales_carlingnationscup.html|archivedate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
On 29 May 2013, Coleman was named Man of the Match for his performance against [[England national football team|England]] at [[Wembley Stadium]]. He crossed the ball for [[Shane Long]]'s opening goal of the game, a header past [[Joe Hart]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegalnow.com/sp/article_manager/detail/coleman_is_man_of_the_match|title=Coleman is man of the match|date=30 May 2013|work=Donegal Now|accessdate=30 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905110248/http://donegalnow.com/sp/article_manager/detail/coleman_is_man_of_the_match|archivedate=5 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highlandradio.com/2013/05/30/coleman-man-of-the-match-at-wembley/|title=Coleman Man of the Match at Wembley|date=30 May 2013|publisher=[[Highland Radio]]|accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref> Coleman captained Ireland for the first time in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group C|2014 World Cup qualifier]] against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 11 October 2013, his 25th birthday, which Ireland lost 3–0 in [[Cologne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-ireland-1126469-Oct2013/|title=Captaining Ireland was a special experience – Seamus Coleman|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Murray|last=Kinsella|date=12 October 2013|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref>
On 31 May 2016, Coleman was selected in [[Martin O'Neill]]'s 23-man squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/news/martin-oneill-names-euro-2016-squad|title=Martin O'Neill names EURO 2016 squad|publisher=Football Association of Ireland|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> At the tournament, he captained Ireland in their final group game victory over Italy. The 1–0 win ensured that the team advanced past the group stages at a [[UEFA European Championship]] for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/i-was-in-a-zone-and-now-captain-coleman-wants-a-repeat-upset-1.2696192|title='I was in a zone' – and now Captain Coleman wants a repeat upset|work=The Irish Times|first=Emmet|last=Malone|date=23 June 2016|accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> He was also captain for Ireland's Round of 16 match against France in [[Lyon]] where the hosts prevailed 2–1 winners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/euro-2016/2016/0626/798306-coleman-it-was-one-that-got-away/|title=Seamus Coleman says it was one that got away|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=26 June 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref>
Coleman was named the permanent Ireland captain in September 2016 following the international retirement of Robbie Keane.<ref name="new captain">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/sport/seamus-coleman-named-the-new-ireland-captain-753137.html|title=Seamus Coleman named the new Ireland captain|work=Irish Examiner|first=Stephen|last=Barry|date=5 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> The following month, he scored his first senior international goal for Ireland in a 1–0 win over [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]] at the [[Aviva Stadium]] in a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group D|2018 World Cup qualifier]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37424268|title=Republic of Ireland 1–0 Georgia|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Richard|last=Petrie|date=6 October 2016|accessdate=8 October 2016}}</ref>
On 24 March 2017, Coleman suffered a broken leg in the 69th minute of a goalless draw in a World Cup qualifier against Wales following a dangerous tackle by Neil Taylor for which the Welshman was given a straight red card.<ref name="bbcsport24mar2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39388290|title=Seamus Coleman suffers broken leg in Republic of Ireland draw|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=24 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/republic-of-ireland/story/3088881/republic-of-irelands-seamus-coleman-suffers-serious-leg-injury-vs-wales|title=Republic of Ireland's Seamus Coleman suffers broken leg against Wales|publisher=ESPN FC|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Coleman received treatment on the pitch and was given oxygen as he was comforted by teammate Shane Long before being carried off on a stretcher.<ref name="doublelegfracture">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/ireland-s-s%C3%A9amus-coleman-undergoes-surgery-on-double-leg-fracture-1.3024950|title=Ireland's Séamus Coleman undergoes surgery on double leg fracture|work=The Irish Times|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/783765/Seamus-Coleman-Broken-Leg-Ireland-Wales-Shane-Long-Reaction|title=Shane Long: This is what Seamus Coleman was like on the field after horror leg break|work=[[Daily Express]]|first=James|last=Cambridge|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He was brought directly to [[Dublin]]'s [[St. Vincent's University Hospital|St. Vincent's Hospital]] where he underwent surgery on a fractured [[tibia]] and [[fibula]] of his right leg.<ref name="doublelegfracture"/> Ireland manager Martin O'Neill stated that Coleman's injury was a "huge blow" to both Ireland and Everton but backed the player to return to his "brilliant" best.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/25/seamus-coleman-martin-oneill-republic-of-ireland-everton|title=Séamus Coleman leg break a huge blow to club and country, says Martin O'Neill|work=The Guardian|first=Stuart|last=James|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/international-soccer/he-will-be-as-brilliant-as-he-was-before-martin-oneill-tips-seamus-coleman-to-get-back-to-his-best-after-hospital-visit-35565180.html|title='He will be as brilliant as he was before' – Martin O'Neill tips Seamus Coleman to get back to his best after hospital visit|work=Irish Independent|first=Damian|last=Spellman|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Taylor's challenge was widely condemned across the football world with the [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] defender himself said to be "devastated" about causing a serious injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2017/0324/862424-coleman-challenge/|title='Appalling and vicious' – RTÉ panel condemn Neil Taylor challenge|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/seamus-coleman-broken-leg-everton-wayne-rooney-criticises-neil-taylor-tackle-wales-republic-of-a7649426.html|title=Wayne Rooney criticises Neil Taylor's 'horrible tackle' that broke Everton's Seamus Coleman's leg|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Jack|last=de Menezes|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/seamus-coleman-leg-break-neil-12796948|title=Seamus Coleman leg break – Neil Taylor devastated after causing Everton man's injury, and tried to apologise afterwards|work=Liverpool Echo|first=Neil|last=Jones|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/enda-kenny-takes-time-out-from-eu-summit-to-condemn-s%C3%A9amus-coleman-tackle-1.3024991|title=Enda Kenny takes time out from EU summit to condemn Séamus Coleman tackle|work=The Irish Times|first=Denis|last=Staunton|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Wales manager [[Chris Coleman (footballer)|Chris Coleman]] later revealed that Taylor went into the Ireland team's changing room to apologise for the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/how-devastated-neil-taylor-tried-12796891|title=How 'devastated' Neil Taylor tried to apologise to Seamus Coleman after the Ireland v Wales match|work=WalesOnline|first=Ian|last=Mitchelmore|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Many fellow footballers, sports personalities and celebrities took to [[Twitter]] to send messages of support to Coleman including [[Wayne Rooney]], [[Shay Given]], [[Héctor Bellerín]], [[Paul McGrath (footballer)|Paul McGrath]], [[Tony Bellew]] and [[Niall Horan]].<ref name="bbcsport24mar2017"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/stars-rally-in-support-of-seamus-coleman-after-everton-man-suffers-broken-leg-35563876.html|title=Stars rally in support of Seamus Coleman after Everton man suffers broken leg|work=Irish Independent|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/sport/tributes-pour-in-for-irelands-seamus-coleman-after-his-horrific-leg-break-against-wales-783084.html|title=Tributes pour in for Ireland's Seamus Coleman after his horrific leg break against Wales|work=Irish Examiner|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> On 26 March, O'Neill confirmed the surgery on the right-back's fractured leg had been a success.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/international-soccer/martin-oneill-seamus-colemans-surgery-was-a-success-35566006.html|title=Martin O'Neill: Seamus Coleman's surgery was a success|work=Irish Independent|date=26 March 2017|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref>
Coleman's first call-up since the injury came for the squad to face [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] on 23 March 2018.<ref name="Return" />
==Style of play== [[File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs Ireland 2013-09-10 - Seamus Coleman 12.JPG|thumb|upright|250px|Coleman running with the ball in a September 2013 [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group C|World Cup qualifier]] against [[Austria national football team|Austria]]. Ireland would eventually be defeated 1–0.]]
Coleman is widely regarded as one of the Premier League's best full-backs.<ref name="Coleman Analysis">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/analysis-seamus-coleman-everton-top-full-backs-1620592-Aug2014/|title=Analysis: Why Seamus Coleman is now regarded as one of Europe’s top full-backs|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Paul|last=Fennessy|date=15 August 2014|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldsoccertalk.com/2013/05/31/the-rise-of-evertons-right-back-seamus-coleman/|title=The Rise of Everton's Right Back Seamus Coleman|publisher=World Soccer Talk|first=Matt|last=Jones|date=31 May 2013|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/news/1156710|title=Ranking the 10 best full-backs in the Premier League|publisher=[[theScore Inc.]]|date=18 November 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-ireland-2-3213599-Jan2017/|title=Coleman sees the League of Ireland as 'the better route' for young players|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Ben|last=Blake|date=31 January 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> A quick, skilful and hard-working player with immense stamina, he is renowned for his eagerness to get forward on attacking runs which has established his goalscoring prowess.<ref name="Coleman Analysis"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punditarena.com/football/nmenezes/why-ireland-captain-seamus-coleman-doesnt-require-a-big-move/|title=Why Ireland Captain Seamus Coleman Doesn't Require A Big Move|publisher=Pundit Arena|first=Nick|last=Menezes|date=2 February 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Coleman has shown a proficiency for having great composure when in possession of the ball and his Everton teammate [[Ashley Williams (footballer)|Ashley Williams]] has hailed him as one of the best players he has ever played with.<ref name="Coleman Analysis"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/evertons-second-best-goalscorer-seamus-coleman-hailed-among-best-teammates-of-ashley-williams-career/923616|title=Everton's second-top scorer: Seamus Coleman hailed among best teammates of Ashley Williams’ career|publisher=Squawka|first=Raj|last=Mahil|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
Despite being very quiet by nature, Coleman has shown great leadership qualities which has propelled him to the role of captain of the Irish national team.<ref name="inspirational">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-captain-ireland-italy-euro-2016-2842292-Jun2016/|title=Captain Coleman gave 'inspirational' speech to players before Ireland's win over Italy|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Ben|last=Blake|date=23 June 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He led the Ireland team out for their final two matches at Euro 2016, earning much praise from teammates, fans and media alike.<ref name="inspirational"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportsjoe.ie/football/seamus-colemans-comments-after-france-shows-why-he-should-captain-ireland-for-the-next-six-years-84678|title=Seamus Coleman's comments after France show why he should captain Ireland for the next six years|publisher=SportsJOE.ie|first=Conan|last=Doherty|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/s%C3%A9amus-coleman-becomes-the-leader-of-the-ireland-pack-1.2698713|title=Séamus Coleman becomes the leader of the Ireland pack|work=The Irish Times|first=Keith|last=Duggan|date=25 June 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He has since taken on the role of Ireland captain on a permanent basis.<ref name="new captain"/> In 2018, it was suggested by ''[[ESPN FC]]'' journalist Luke O'Farrell that Coleman should also be the next club captain at Everton, highlighting that the full-back "leads by example and, more importantly, demands more from his teammates. Coleman has never been afraid to let another player know when something is not working or needs improvement. [...] Coleman sets the mark for the rest of the team to follow".<ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce must make Seamus Coleman captain to inspire supporters|first=Luke|last=O'Farrell|work=ESPN FC|date=9 March 2018|accessdate=9 March 2018|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/everton/368/blog/post/3412469/sam-allardyce-must-make-seamus-coleman-captain-to-inspire-supporters}}</ref>
==Personal life== Coleman has two brothers: Francis and Stephen (known as Stevie). His parents are Máire and Henry Coleman.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/everton-footballer-seamus-coleman-visits-tinahely-ns-27854919.html|title=Everton footballer Seamus Coleman visits Tinahely NS|work=Wicklow People|date=7 July 2010|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Stevie has [[cerebral palsy]] and participated in the [[2003 Special Olympics World Summer Games]] football event where the Irish team won bronze medals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-special-olympics-collection-1407146-Apr2014/|title=My brother Stevie got the skills, says Special Olympics ambassador Seamus Coleman|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Niall|last=Kelly|date=11 April 2014|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> As a boy, Coleman attended St. Catherine's Vocational School.<ref>{{cite web|title=Killybegs drill Charlestown on the spot|url=http://www.fais.ie/news/459/killybegs-drill-charlestown-on-the-spot/|publisher=FAI Schools|date=11 February 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105041624/http://www.fais.ie/news/459/killybegs-drill-charlestown-on-the-spot/|archivedate=5 November 2013}}</ref> He supports the [[Donegal GAA|Donegal senior football team]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2012/08/27/picture-special-more-of-your-incredible-donegal-celebration-pix-from-around-the-globe/|title=Picture special: More of your incredible Donegal celebration pix from around the globe|work=Donegal Daily|date=27 August 2012|accessdate=27 August 2012|quote=Seamus Coleman very politely and willingly stops to make Sean Thomas McMonagle, Mecheala and Nicole Cronin's day!}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2012/08/27/ddtv-video-of-a-donegal-fans-day-at-croke-park/|title=DDTV: Video of a Donegal fan's day at Croke Park|work=Donegal Daily|date=27 August 2012|accessdate=27 August 2012|quote=The GAA slogan says that you can't beat being there. And you really can't...There's even a cameo role later on from Seamus Coleman!}}</ref> He also still follows his local GAA team, [[C.L.G. Na gCealla Beaga|Na Cealla Beaga]],<ref name=defy_logic_injury-hit_shock_title_success/> and attended the final of the [[2013 Donegal Senior Football Championship]] when they lost to [[Glenswilly GAA|Gleann tSuilí]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Fennessy|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-pic-kilybegs-donegal-county-final-1139023-Oct2013/|title=Seamus Coleman was at the Glenswilly-Killybegs game today|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|date=20 October 2013|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref>
{{cquote|I'd be more nervous watching the [Gaelic football] lads than I would be watching my own games [...] When it's Killybegs playing, it means a bit more. It's something I was a big part of growing up, I played with all them lads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/Donegal/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=202579|title=Killybegs win delights Coleman|publisher=[[Hogan Stand]]|date=10 October 2013|accessdate=10 October 2013}}</ref>}}
In June 2015, he married Rachel Cunningham in St. Mary of the Visitation Church in Killybegs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evoke.ie/showbiz/ireland-midfielder-seamus-coleman-marries-childhood-sweethear/|website=EVOKE.ie|title=Pitch perfect! Football star Séamus Coleman marries his childhood sweetheart|date=21 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304123503/http://evoke.ie/showbiz/ireland-midfielder-seamus-coleman-marries-childhood-sweetheart |archivedate=4 March 2016}}</ref> and their daughter, Lilly, was born in February the following year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/bring-sleepless-nights-says-everton-10854005|title=Bring on sleepless nights says Everton goal hero Seamus Coleman|work=Liverpool Echo|first=David|last=Prentice|date=7 February 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>

youthclubs2 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | years1 = 2015–2017 | clubs1 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | caps1 = 45 | goals1 = 10 | years2 = 2017– | clubs2 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | caps2 = 30 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2018 | clubs3 = → [[RB Leipzig]] (loan) | caps3 = 11 | goals3 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2016 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football nationalteam-update = 22:41, 11 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Ademola Lookman Olajade Alade Aylola Lookman''' (born 20 October 1997) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] of the [[Premier League]], and for the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]]. Lookman made his senior debut in 2015, playing as a [[forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Charlton Athletic]] of the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], and in January 2017 signed for Everton, who have used him mainly as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]. He has represented England from [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] to [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 levels]]. ==Early life== Lookman was born in [[Wandsworth]], [[London]]. He attended [[St Thomas the Apostle College]] in [[Peckham]] where he achieved three A*s and five As at GCSE.{{cite news |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/how-ademola-lookman-slipped-through-the-cracks-before-making-his-11million-move-to-everton-a7512746.html |title=How Ademola Lookman slipped through the academy net before making his £11m move to Everton |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=6 January 2017 |accessdate=15 January 2017}} ==Club career== ===Charlton Athletic=== Lookman joined [[Charlton Athletic]]'s academy in 2014 after signing from Waterloo, a youth football club based in the [[London Borough of Lambeth]].{{cite news |url=http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/article.cfm?id=114672&headline=Charlton%20keen%20to%20secure%20teenage%20prospect%20Ademola%20Lookman%20to%20new%20contract§ionIs=sport&searchyear=2015 |title=Charlton keen to secure teenage prospect Ademola Lookman to new contract |first=Richard |last=Cawley |newspaper=South London Press |date=27 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208170257/http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/article.cfm?id=114672&headline=Charlton%20keen%20to%20secure%20teenage%20prospect%20Ademola%20Lookman%20to%20new%20contract§ionIs=sport&searchyear=2015 |archivedate=8 December 2015}} His goalscoring record for Charlton's U18 and U21 teams led to him making a rapid ascent through the Charlton academy ranks and he made his first-team debut for the Addicks on 3 November 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/fixtures-results/match-report/index.aspx?matchid=3833373 |title=Match report: MK Dons 1–0 Charlton |first=George |last=Jones |publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C. |date=3 November 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117015323/https://www.cafc.co.uk/fixtures-results/match-report/index.aspx?matchid=3833373 |archivedate=17 November 2015}} He scored his first goal for the club in a 3–2 defeat at [[Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 5 December 2015,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34951482|title=Brighton 3-2 Charlton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 December 2015 |accessdate=2 January 2016}} and then followed that up with both Charlton's goals in a 2–2 draw with [[Bolton Wanderers]] ten days later.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35036029|title=Charlton 2-2 Bolton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 December 2015 |accessdate=2 January 2016}} ===Everton=== Lookman signed a four-and-a-half-year contract with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 5 January 2017 for an undisclosed fee, reported as an initial £7.5m potentially rising to £11m with add-ons.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/10718733/everton-sign-ademola-lookman-from-charlton-for-7-5m |title=Everton sign Ademola Lookman from Charlton for £7.5m |first=Paul |last=Vinnell |publisher=Sky Sports |date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38520520 |title=Ademola Lookman: Everton sign Charlton forward for £11m |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 January 2017|accessdate=5 January 2017}} He made his debut for the club ten days later in a 4–0 victory over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], replacing [[Ross Barkley]] in the 90th minute and scoring the team's fourth goal.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38545988|title=Everton 4-0 Manchester City |first=Luke |last=Reddy |publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 January 2017|accessdate=4 September 2017}} Lookman made his first Euro appearance for Everton in a 1–0 win over [[MFK Ružomberok]] in the [[2017–18 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] third qualifying round first leg.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40724022 |title=Baines gives Everton Europa lead on Rooney return |date=27 July 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Tom |last=Rostance |accessdate=27 July 2017 }} Although manager [[Sam Allardyce]] stated that Lookman would not be leaving on loan in the January 2018 transfer window, he changed his mind, and the club arranged a move to Championship club [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], where they hoped he would play regular first-team football. However, the player insisted on an alternative move, and joined [[Bundesliga]] club [[RB Leipzig]] until the end of the 2017–18 season.{{cite news |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/everton-wanted-ademola-lookman-stay-14232472 |title=Everton wanted Ademola Lookman to stay in England with Championship club |first=Phil |last=Kirkbride |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=1 February 2018 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/02/01/everton-boss-sam-allardyce-claims-ademola-lookmans-stubbornness-took-him-rb-leipzig-over-derby |title=Everton boss Sam Allardyce claims Ademola Lookman's 'stubbornness' took him to RB Leipzig over Derby |website=Sports Illustrated |date=1 February 2018 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}
{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/11231037/ademola-lookman-joins-rb-leipzig-on-loan-from-everton |title=Ademola Lookman joins RB Leipzig on loan from Everton |first=Rory |last=O'Callaghan |publisher=Sky Sports |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=2 February 2018}} In his first game with Leipzig, Lookman scored the winning goal in the away game against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] after coming on as a late substitute.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2018/feb/05/ademola-lookman-slips-slides-from-everton-into-leipzig-affections |title=Ademola Lookman slips and slides from Everton into Leipzig’s affections |first=Andy|last= Brassell |date= 5 February 2018 |work=The Guardian }} ==International career== Lookman was born in England to parents from Nigeria, and is eligible for the national teams of both countries.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38680392 |title=Nigeria keen on England U20 striker Ademola Lookman |first=Oluwashina |last=Okeleji |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 January 2017 |accessdate=23 January 2017}} He received his first international call-up when he was named in the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] squad for two matches against [[Mexico national under-19 football team|Mexico]].{{cite web|last=Veevers |first=Nicholas |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2016/may/england-under-19s-squad-named-for-mexico-150516 |title=England Under-19s squad named for double-header with Mexico |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 May 2016 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} He was subsequently named in the squad for the [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|European U19 Championships]] that summer.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2016/jul/under-19s-euro-squad-named-060716|title=England Under-19s squad named for Euro Finals challenge |first=Nicholas |last=Veeves |publisher=The Football Association |date=6 July 2016 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} In early 2017, Lookman turned down the opportunity to switch allegiance to Nigeria after an approach from the national coach, [[Gernot Rohr]].{{cite web |url=http://allnigeriasoccer.com/read_news.php?nid=22250 |title=Everton rising star Lookman turns down chance to represent Nigeria ahead of FIFA U20 World Cup |website=All Nigeria Soccer |date=3 March 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} Lookman was selected in the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] for the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. He scored three goals in the tournament, two against [[Costa Rica national under-20 football team|Costa Rica]] in the last 16.{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/how-evertons-england-world-cup-13169997 |title=How Everton's England World Cup heroes fared in South Korea - and what the future holds for them at Goodison |first=Kristian |last=Walsh |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=11 June 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} England beat [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela]] 1–0 in the final, to achieve the country's first victory in the final of a global tournament since the [[1966 FIFA World Cup|1966 World Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40237981 |title=Under-20 World Cup: England beat Venezuela in final |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 June 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} He received his first call-up for the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21s]] for [[2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|European Championship qualifiers]] against the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands under-21s]] and [[Latvia national under-21 football team|Latvia under-21s]] in September 2017.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/11003712/ten-u20-world-cup-heroes-given-first-england-u21-call-ups |title=Ten U20 World Cup heroes given first England U21 call-ups |first=Lyall |last=Thomas |publisher=Sky Sports |date=24 August 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} He made his debut in the first match, and set up Everton teammate [[Dominic Calvert-Lewin]] for England's goal in a 1–1 draw.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41130408 |title=Netherlands U21 1–1 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=4 September 2017}} ==Career
