{{short description|English association football player}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jonjoe Kenny | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Jonjoe Kenny<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1997|3|15}}<ref name="11v11">{{cite web |title=Jonjoe Kenny |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/jonjoe-kenny-248410/ |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=20 October 2017}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Liverpool]], England | height = {{convert|1.76|m|order=flip}}<ref name="11v11"/> | position = [[Right-back]] | currentclub = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | clubnumber = 43 | youthyears1 = 2006–2014 | youthclubs1 = [[Everton F.C. Reserves and Academy|Everton]] | years1 = 2014– | caps1 = 30 | goals1 = 0 | clubs1 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | years2 = 2015 | caps2 = 7 | goals2 = 0 | clubs2 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | years3 = 2016 | caps3 = 17 | goals3 = 0 | clubs3 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | nationalyears1 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2013–2014 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 10 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 10 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2016–2017 | nationalteam5 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps5 = 14 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | nationalyears6 = 2017– | nationalteam6 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps6 = 13 | nationalgoals6 = 0 | club-update = 19:18, 12 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 22:37, 11 October 2018 (UTC)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/k/jonjoe-kenny |title=Jonjoe Kenny |publisher=The FA |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> }} '''Jonjoe Kenny''' (born 15 March 1997)<ref>{{cite web|title=Jonjoe Kenny|url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2014/teams/player=250066938/index.html|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[right-back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]]. He came through the youth system of the [[Premier League]] side, where he has been a professional since July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2014/07/18/youngsters-sign-pro-deals |title=Youngsters Sign Pro Deals |publisher=Everton |date=18 July 2014 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
==Club career== Kenny signed on loan for [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 21 July 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33616967 |title=Everton's Francisco Junior & Jonjoe Kenny join Wigan on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 July 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> Having played seven times for the first team, he returned to Everton at the end of the loan, despite Wigan manager [[Gary Caldwell]] expressing a desire to extend the deal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/jonjoe-kenny-returns-to-everton-following-loan-2702459.aspx |title=Defender Jonjoe Kenny's returns to Everton following loan.|publisher=Wigan Athletic |date=22 September 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
On 27 January 2016, Kenny joined [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] of [[EFL League Two|League Two]], initially on a one-month loan,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oufc.co.uk/news/article/oxford-united-kenny-everton-2924023.aspx |title=Oxford United Sign Jonjoe Kenny |publisher=Oxford United F.C. |date=27 January 2016 |accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref> later extended to the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/14391838.Jonjoe_Kenny_to_stay_at_Oxford_United_for_run_in_after_Everton_agree_to_loan_extension/ |title=Jonjoe Kenny to stay at Oxford United for run-in after Everton agree to loan extension|first=David |last=Pritchard |newspaper=Oxford Mail |date=30 March 2016 |accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
He made his Premier League debut for Everton, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Matthew Pennington]] against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], on 15 May 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240381 |title=Everton 3 Norwich City 0|publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 May 2016 |accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref> His second Premier League appearance was again as a substitute, for [[Mason Holgate]] against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 6 May 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39754033|title=Swansea 1 Everton 0|publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 May 2017 |accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
Kenny began the 2017/18 season as 4th choice under Ronald Koeman, however soon impressed when given his chance. He made his first Premier League start on the 22nd October at home to Arsenal in a 5-2 defeat. Following Koemans sacking, he made 13 consecutive starts in the league, playing in 16 out of 19 games from October until the return of Seamus Coleman in January. He played 25 games in all competitions, starting 23, and scored 0 goals.
'''2018/19'''
The following season began with Kenny as back up to Coleman, before impressing as the Irishman suffered with a foot injury. He played 4 Premier League games in a row. Following the win away to Leicester on 6th October, he was dropped out of the starting XI and didn't play again until New Year's Day, again against Leicester, this time in a 1-0 defeat. He kept his place for an FA Cup 3rd round win over Lincoln City. He returned the XI on the 28th January in a 1-0 victory over Huddersfield Town, coming on as a makeshift left back for the final 20 minutes, following an injury to Leighton Baines and a red card for his substitute Lucas Digne. He continued at left back against Wolves 4 days later, coming on for Leighton Baines on the 20th minute. After impressing, he played the following 2 matches against Man City and Watford in which he picked up the Man of the Match award.
== International career == In May 2014, Kenny was part of the [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17]] side that won the [[2014 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].<ref name="U17 Champions">{{cite web|title=England win European Under-17 Championship on penalties|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27512259|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 May 2014|accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref> In the final, Kenny converted the match-winning penalty in the [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] against the [[Netherlands national under-17 football team|Netherlands]].<ref name="U17 Champions"/> He was named in UEFA's team of the tournament.<ref name="technical report">{{cite web|title=Technical Report|url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2014/technical-report/tr-under17-2014.pdf|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref>
Kenny was a member of the England squad for the [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], starting in the semi-final defeat against [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Italy down England with Dimarco double|url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2016/matches/round=2000599/match=2020324/index.html|accessdate=17 June 2017|work=UEFA|date=21 July 2016}}</ref>
Kenny was selected for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] in the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. He played in all seven matches of the tournament. In the final England beat [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela]] 1–0, which is England's first win in a global tournament since their [[1966 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] victory of 1966.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40237981 |title= Under-20 World Cup: England beat Venezuela in final |work=BBC Sport |date= 11 June 2017 | }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Use British English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Mason Holgate | image = 2017083201424 2017-03-24 Fussball U21 Deutschland vs England - Sven - 1D X - 0196 - DV3P6522 - Holgate.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Holgate playing for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] in 2017 | fullname = Mason Anthony Holgate{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|10|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Doncaster]], England | height = {{convert|1.84|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/10564/Mason-Holgate/overview |title=Mason Holgate: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=11 February 2018}} | position = [[Centre back]] | currentclub = [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]
(on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]) | clubnumber = 68 | youthyears1 = 2005–2014 | youthclubs1 = [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] | years1 = 2014–2015 | clubs1 = [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] | caps1 = 20 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2015– | clubs2 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | caps2 = 38 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2019– | clubs3 = → [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] (loan) | caps3 = 11 | goals3 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2016– | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 6 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 20:41, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:52, 1 July 2017 (UTC) }} '''Mason Anthony Holgate''' (born 22 October 1996) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] of the {{English football updater|WestBrom}}, on loan from {{English football updater|Everton}} club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], and the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]]. He can also operate as a [[right back]]. ==Club career== ===Barnsley=== Holgate was born in [[Doncaster]], [[South Yorkshire]] and joined [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at the age of nine.{{cite web|url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/reds-youngster-mason-holgate-signs-professional-contract-1961514.aspx|title=Reds Youngster Mason Holgate Signs Professional Contract|publisher=Barnsley F.C.|date=25 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927042905/http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/reds-youngster-mason-holgate-signs-professional-contract-1961514.aspx|archivedate=27 September 2014 |deadurl=no}} Having progressed through the club's academy and reserve team, Holgate signed his first professional contract, keeping him at Barnsley until 2016. He made his [[Football League One|League One]] debut for Barnsley on 2 December 2014, playing the full ninety minutes of a 1–1 draw with [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] at [[Oakwell]].{{cite news|title=Barnsley 1 – 1 Doncaster|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28993024|accessdate=25 January 2015|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=2 December 2014}} Following this, the club were determined to negotiate a longer term contract for Holgate. After inclusion in the first team, Holgate scored his first Barnsley goal, in a 5–0 win over [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on the last game of the season.{{cite news|title=Barnsley 5 – 0 Rochdale|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32471219|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 May 2015|accessdate=18 August 2015}} Following a successful [[2014–15 Barnsley F.C. season|debut season]] at Barnsley, Holgate was named 2014–15 Young Player of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/top-awards-for-hourihane-winnall-nyatanga-2440652.aspx|title=Top Awards for Hourihane, Winnall & Nyatanga|publisher=Barnsley F.C.|date=5 May 2015|accessdate=18 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507211430/http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/top-awards-for-hourihane-winnall-nyatanga-2440652.aspx|archivedate=7 May 2015 |deadurl=no}} In addition to this award, press speculation linked Holgate with a number of [[Premier League]] clubs; {{cite news|title=Mason Holgate: Barnsley aim to tie teenager to new deal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30624830|accessdate=25 January 2015|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=29 December 2014}} in July 2015, he went on trial at [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3162955/Manchester-United-hand-trial-Barnsley-defender-Mason-Holgate.html "Manchester United hand trial to Barnsley defender Mason Holgate in bid to ward off interest from Aston Villa and Swansea"] Daily Mail. 15 July 2015. Retrieved 17 July 2015.{{Unreliable source|date=September 2018}} ===Everton=== On 13 August 2015 Holgate signed a five-year deal to join Premier League side [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] for a reported fee of £2 million.{{Cite web|title = Blues Complete Holgate Deal {{!}} Everton Football Club|url = http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2015/08/13/blues-complete-holgate-deal|publisher = Everton F.C.|accessdate = 2015-08-13}}{{cite web|last1=Whalley|first1=Mike|title=Everton sign Mason Holgate from Barnsley on five-year contract|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2561755/everton-sign-mason-holgate-from-barnsley|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|accessdate=13 August 2015|date=13 August 2015}} On 13 August 2016, a year after he signed for the club, Holgate made his Premier League debut in the 1–1 draw with Tottenham Hotspur in the [[Premier League]]. ====West Bromwich Albion (loan)==== On 31 December 2018, Holgate joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on loan until the end of the [[2018–19 EFL Championship|season]].{{Cite web|title = Albion add first January recruit|url = https://www.wba.co.uk/news/2018/december/albion-add-first-january-recruit/|publisher = West Bromwich Albion F.C.|accessdate = 2018-12-31}} ==International career== Holgate is of Jamaican descent through his grandparents, and is eligible to represent both England and Jamaica internationally.{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/03/22/yorkshire-blue|title=Yorkshire Blue - Everton Football Club|publisher=Everton F.C.}} Holgate was the starting right back for [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] during the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in June 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.whoscored.com/Players/297544/Show/Mason-Holgate|title=Mason Holgate|publisher=Whoscored.com}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 16 Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] (loan) | caps11 = 7 | goals11 = 4 | nationalyears1 = 2013– | nationalteam1 = [[DR Congo national football team|DR Congo]] | nationalcaps1 = 33 | nationalgoals1 = 9 | club-update = 23:25, 17 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 13:58, 16 June 2018 (UTC) }} '''Yannick Bolasie''' (born 24 May 1989) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. Born in [[Lyon]], he has played in [[the Football League]] for [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]], [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. Bolasie has been [[Cap (sport)|capped]] at international level by the [[DR Congo national football team|Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Bolasie began his career with [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] at age 16. He spent four months as a member of their youth team and then had a spell with [[Hillingdon Borough F.C.|Hillingdon Borough]] in the [[Southern Football League]] before moving across Europe to play for [[Floriana F.C.|Floriana]] in the [[Maltese Premier League]].{{cite news|title=Il-ħabib personali Malti tal-plejer ta' Everton Bolasie|url=http://www.one.com.mt/news/il-habib-personali-malti-tal-plejer-ta-everton-bolasie/|work=[[One (Maltese TV channel)|One News]]|date=22 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304081138/http://www.one.com.mt/news/il-habib-personali-malti-tal-plejer-ta-everton-bolasie/|archivedate=4 March 2016 |language=mt}}[http://www.thediamondsfc.com/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10784~43988,00.html "Yannick Bolasie"] Rushden & Diamonds; Retrieved 10 August 2010 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201065643/http://www.thediamondsfc.com/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10784~43988,00.html |date=1 December 2008 }} He returned to England in 2008 after being offered a trial with [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] and impressed enough to be offered a two-year contract.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/7512355.stm "Teenager Bolasie opts for Argyle"] BBC Sport, 17 July 2008; Retrieved 10 August 2010 He joined [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] on trial with a view to a loan move[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/7644168.stm "Bolasie back from Daggers trial"] BBC Sport, 30 September 2008; Retrieved 10 August 2010 before returning to Rushden & Diamonds on loan near the end of the year.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rushden_and_diamonds/7742855.stm "Rushden sign Plymouth midfielder"] BBC Sport, 21 November 2008; Retrieved 10 August 2010 He made his debut against [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]] on 29 November,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/7727623.stm "Rushden 2–0 Eastbourne"] BBC Sport, 22 November 2008; Retrieved 10 August 2010 and made seven appearances in the [[2008–09 Football Conference|Conference]] before returning to Argyle in January 2009. Bolasie then joined [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on loan,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/barnet/7845749.stm "Bolasie makes Barnet loan switch"] BBC Sport, 22 January 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 making his [[Football League]] debut against [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] on 24 January 2009.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7844305.stm "Accrington 1–1 Barnet"] BBC Sport, 23 January 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 He scored his first goal two weeks later, opening the scoring in a 3–3 draw against [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7869550.stm "Barnet 3–3 Grimsby"] BBC Sport, 10 February 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 Bolasie returned to Argyle at the end of the [[2008–09 Football League|2008–09 season]] having made 20 league appearances for Barnet, scoring three goals.[http://www.soccerbase.com/squad_season.sd?seasonid=138&teamid=344 "Barnet 2008/2009 player appearances"] Soccerbase; Retrieved 10 August 2010 The club's manager, [[Ian Hendon]], was keen to bring Bolasie back, but dismissed the chances of signing him permanently. Hendon said, "Yannick is still under contract at Plymouth, so it is likely that he will return there at the end of the season."[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11705_5187907,00.html "Hendon keen to keep trio"] Sky Sports, 14 April 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 He rejoined the Barnet squad in July 2009 ahead of the new season on a six-month loan,[http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1719360,00.html "Benefit time"] Plymouth Argyle; Retrieved 10 August 2010 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090713022909/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10364~1719360,00.html |date=13 July 2009 }} and hoped it would act as a springboard to winning a place in the Argyle [[first team]].[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11688_5487285,00.html "Bolasie eyes Pilgrims future"] Sky Sports, 12 August 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 Bolasie scored against Grimsby again in October 2009, capping a fine display with a fierce shot from 30 yards[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/8273393.stm "Barnet 3–0 Grimsby"] BBC Sport, 3 October 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 Bolasie scored his second goal of the season three weeks later against [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]],[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/8306899.stm "Barnet 3–0 Darlington"] BBC Sport, 24 October 2009; Retrieved 10 August 2010 as Hendon's side maintained a place in the top half of the [[2009–10 Football League Two|League Two]] table.[http://www.statto.com/football/teams/barnet/2009-2010 "2009–10 Barnet season"] Statto.com (Statto Organisation Limited) Retrieved 10 August 2010 ===Plymouth Argyle=== [[File:Yannick Bolasie.jpg|thumb|upright|Bolasie training with [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] in 2010]] Bolasie returned to Plymouth Argyle in January 2010,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/barnet/8448445.stm "Bees Bolasie returns to Plymouth"] BBC Sport, 8 January 2010; Retrieved 10 August 2010 having made a further 22 league appearances for Barnet, scoring twice.[http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=344&teamTabs=stats "Barnet 2009/2010 player appearances"] Soccerbase; Retrieved 10 August 2010 He was given a chance to impress by [[Paul Mariner]], who had succeeded Sturrock a month earlier, and included him in the squad to take on [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on 13 February 2010.[http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/BENCH-DUTY-BOLASIE/story-11479994-detail/story.html#axzz2PDNjjqbs Bench duty for Bolasie] This is Cornwall (Local World), 16 February 2010 He made his debut for the club in that game, coming off the substitute bench to provide the momentum to turn a one nil deficit into a 3–1 win for the visitors.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8508484.stm "Barnsley 1–3 Plymouth"] BBC Sport, 13 February 2010; Retrieved 13 February 2010 He scored his first goal for the club two weeks later at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8534714.stm "Sheff Utd 4–3 Plymouth"] BBC Sport, 27 February 2010; Retrieved 27 February 2010 The pacy winger,[http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/Winger-Bolasie-Home-Park-hopes/story-11463509-detail/story.html#axzz2PDNjjqbs Winger Bolasie has Home Park hopes] This is Cornwall (Local World), 14 August 2009; Retrieved 1 April 2013 ended the season with 16 [[2009–10 Football League Championship|Championship]] appearances to his name,[http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2036&teamTabs=stats "Plymouth 2009/2010 player appearances"] Soccerbase; Retrieved 10 August 2010 but could not prevent the club from being relegated to [[Football League One|League One]]. Bolasie was offered a new contract by the club in April 2010,[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6118172,00.html "Bolasie keen on new deal"] Sky Sports; 26 April 2010; Retrieved 10 August 2010 and Bolasie signed it in July after the arrival of [[Peter Reid]] as the club's new manager.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/8777368.stm "Bolasie signs new deal at Argyle"] BBC Sport, 30 June 2010; Retrieved 10 August 2010 ===Bristol City=== Bolasie was transferred to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 6 June 2011 for an undisclosed fee and signed a two-year contract.{{cite news|title=Bristol City sign Plymouth Argyle's Yannick Bolasie|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13595516.stm| publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=6 June 2011}}{{cite news|title=Bristol City manager Keith Millen delighted as Yannick Bolasie set to sign|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Bristol-City-manager-Keith-Millen-delighted/story-12717390-detail/story.html|accessdate=6 June 2011|work=This is Bristol|publisher=Local World|date=6 June 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609205517/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Bristol-City-manager-Keith-Millen-delighted/story-12717390-detail/story.html#|archive-date=9 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} He scored his first goal for the club in a 3–1 win against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on 9 April 2012.{{cite news|title=Bristol City 3–1 Coventry|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17581337|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 April 2012|date=9 April 2012}} Prior to the match against Barnsley later that month, Bolasie was named Young Player of the Year by the Supporters Club and Trust after a fans vote.{{cite web|title=Jon Lands Top Fans' Award|url=http://www.bcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10327~2743276,00.html|publisher=Bristol City F.C|accessdate=22 April 2012|date=21 April 2012}} He submitted a written transfer request in August 2012 because he wanted to move back to London.{{cite news|title=Bristol City's Yannick Bolasie submits transfer request|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19312112|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=19 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Yannick Bolasie asks to leave Bristol City as Crystal Palace wait to swoop|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Yannick-Bolasie-asks-leave-Bristol-City-Crystal/story-16733203-detail/story.html|accessdate=27 January 2013|work=This is Bristol|publisher=Local World|date=19 August 2012}} ===Crystal Palace=== In August 2012, Bolasie signed a three-year contract with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] for an undisclosed fee.{{cite web|title=Freedman Ties Up Bolasie Deal|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2012/august/freedman-ties-up-bolasie-deal/|publisher=Crystal Palace F.C|accessdate=24 August 2012|date=24 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Crystal Palace sign Darcy Blake, Yannick Bolasie and Andre Mortiz|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19360842|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=24 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Crystal Palace sign Bristol City winger|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/sport-football/crystal_palace_sign_bristol_city_winger_1_1494092|accessdate=27 January 2013|work=Ilford Recorder|publisher= Archant Community Media|date=24 August 2012}} He made his debut in a 2–1 defeat at [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],{{cite news|last=Ritson|first=Mark|title=Darcy Blake, Yannick Bolasie and Andre Moritz impress Dougie Freedman|url=http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/Darcy-Blake-Yannick-Bolasie-Andre-Moritz-impress/story-16771217-detail/story.html|accessdate=27 January 2013|work=This is Croydon Today|publisher=Local World|date=27 August 2012}} and scored his first goal for Palace in a 5–0 home win against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. He was an unused substitute for Palace in the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final]] as the ''Eagles'' defeated [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] 1–0 to gain promotion to the [[Premier League]] for the [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14 season]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/27/crystal-palace-watford-live-championship-play-off-final|title=Crystal Palace v Watford – as it happened|date=28 May 2013|work=The Guardian}} Bolasie made his Premier League debut as a substitute against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 5 October 2013.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24350200|title=Liverpool 3–1 Crystal Palace|date=5 October 2013|work=BBC}} He was [[Ejection (sports)#Association football|sent-off]] in the 78th minute of a 1–0 win at [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on 23 November 2013,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24968969|title=Hull 0–1 Crystal Palace|date=23 November 2013|work=BBC}} and scored his first Premier League goal in a 3–2 win over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] at [[Goodison Park]] on 21 September 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29196080|title=Everton 2–3 Crystal Palace|date=21 September 2014|work=BBC}} On 11 April 2015, Bolasie scored an 11-minute [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|hat-trick]] against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in a 4–1 win at the [[Stadium of Light]], becoming the first Crystal Palace player to score a hat-trick in the Premier League.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32180018 |title=Sunderland 0–4 Crystal Palace |date=11 April 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}{{cite web | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11706/9801543/palace-players-pay-tribute-to-bolasie-after-hat-trick | title=Crystal Palace players hail Yannick Bolasie after hat-trick | publisher=Sky Sports | accessdate=12 April 2015}} He signed a new three-and-a-half-year deal for Crystal Palace early in the 2015–16 season.{{cite web|title=Yannick Bolasie signs new Crystal Palace contract|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34371693|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 September 2015|date=26 September 2015}} ===Everton=== On 15 August 2016, Bolasie joined [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] for a reported £25 million transfer fee.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37083859|title=Yannick Bolasie: Everton sign midfielder from Crystal Palace for £25m|work=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2016|accessdate=15 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/15/yannick-bolasie-signs-everton-crystal-palace|title=Yannick Bolasie signs for Everton from Crystal Palace for £25m|work=The Guardian|date=15 August 2016|accessdate=15 August 2016|author=Fifield, Dominic}} He made his debut as a substitute in a 2–1 win away against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] five days later,{{cite news|last1=Kirkbride|first1=Phil|title=West Brom 1–2 Everton full time report: Blues come from behind to give Ronald Koeman first win as boss|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-1-2-everton-11777428|accessdate=24 August 2016|work=Liverpool Echo|date=20 August 2016}} and three days after that made his first start for Everton, in a 4–0 [[EFL Cup]] win at home to [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]].{{cite news|last1=Jolly|first1=Richard|title=Arouna Koné scores two late goals as Everton cruise past Yeovil|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/23/everton-yeovil-efl-cup-match-report|accessdate=24 August 2016|work=The Guardian|date=23 August 2014}} Bolasie sustained an injury to his right [[anterior cruciate ligament]] in a 1–1 draw with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 4 December 2016,{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=The|title=Bolasie out for the season|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/bolasie-out-for-the-season-zt6czf5rk|accessdate=31 December 2016|work=The Times|date=6 December 2016}} and was out injured until 26 December 2017.{{cite web | last=James | first=Stuart | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/dec/26/west-bromwich-albion-everton-premier-league-match-report | title=West Brom's Craig Dawson tops list of missed chances against Everton | work=The Guardian | date=26 December 2017 | accessdate=30 December 2017}} === Aston Villa === On 25 August 2018, Bolasie signed for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on a season-long loan from Everton.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45281262|title=Yannick Bolasie: Aston Villa sign Everton winger on season-long loan|last=|first=|date=25 August 2018|work=[[BBC Sport]]|access-date=25 August 2018}} He returned to Everton from his loan early on 21 January 2019.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/21/evertons-yannick-bolasie-set-to-cut-short-aston-villa-loan-spell|title=Everton’s Yannick Bolasie cuts short Aston Villa loan spell|last=James|first=Stuart|date=21 January 2019|work=The Guardian|access-date=21 January 2019}} ===Anderlecht=== Bolasie signed for Belgian side [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] on loan for the remainder of the 2018–19 season.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47073854 |title=Idrissa Gueye: Everton reject Paris St-Germain bid as Yannick Bolasie is loaned out |publisher=BBC Sport |last=McNulty |first=Phil |date=31 January 2019 |accessdate=1 February 2019}} ==International career== Bolasie was eligible to represent France, England and DR Congo internationally through birth, upbringing and heritage respectively. In January 2013 while playing in the Championship for Crystal Palace, Bolasie rejected the chance to represent the DR Congo in the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations]] claiming that he did not want to disrupt making progress in his club career.{{cite news|last=Aarons|first=Ed|title=Africa Cup of Nations 2013: Bolasie rejects DR Congo call-up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20831198|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=23 December 2012}} In March 2013, Bolasie was again called up to the [[DR Congo national football team|Democratic Republic of Congo squad]],{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11706/8578947/Yannick-Bolasie-delighted-to-be-playing-for-DR-Congo|title=Yannick Bolasie delighted to be playing for DR Congo|author=Graeme Bailey|work=Sky Sports|publisher=BSkyB|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=1 April 2013}} and made his international debut{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=367629/index.html|title=Bolasie Yannick YALA|publisher=FIFA|work=FIFA.com|accessdate=1 April 2013}} in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|2014 World Cup qualification]] 0–0 draw with [[Libya national football team|Libya]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/matches/round=258334/match=300181940/index.html|title=Congo DR 0–0 Libya|publisher=FIFA|work=FIFA.com|date=24 March 2013|accessdate=1 April 2013}} Bolasie was selected in the Congolese squad for the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations]] in [[Equatorial Guinea]]. He scored the equaliser in their first group game, a 1–1 draw against Zambia at the [[Nuevo Estadio de Ebebiyín]] on 18 January.{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Zambia 1–1 DR Congo|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30766342|accessdate=18 January 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=18 January 2015}} The team finished in third place. ==Personal life== His parents were born in [[Zaire]], now the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Bolasie was born in the French city of [[Lyon]],{{cite news|title=Reid: Yannick Bolasie has a lot to learn but could be a success|url=http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/Reid-Yannick-Bolasie-lot-learn-success/story-12722660-detail/story.html|accessdate=27 January 2013|work=This is Plymouth|publisher=Local World|date=7 June 2011}}{{cite news|last=Prentki|first=Tom|title=Crystal Palace striker Glenn Murray returns to haunt Brighton manager Gus Poyet with double strike |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/championship/9717713/Crystal-Palace-striker-Glenn-Murray-returns-to-haunt-Brighton-manager-Gus-Poyet-with-double-strike.html|accessdate=27 January 2013|work=The Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|date=2 December 2012}}{{cite news|last=Gentry|first=Nick|title=Eagles winger just happy to be playing again after Bristol City nightmare| url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/sport/football/palace/10084856.Eagles_winger_just_happy_to_be_playing_again_after_Bristol_City_nightmare/|work=News Shopper|publisher=Newsquest|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=3 December 2012}} but moved to England when he was seven months old and grew up in the London borough of [[London Borough of Brent|Brent]].{{cite web|last=Bailey|first=Graeme|title=Buzzing Bolasie|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11706/8495165/Buzzing-Bolasie|work=Sky Sports|publisher=BSkyB|accessdate=12 February 2013|date=12 February 2013}}{{cite news|last=Cawley|first=Richard|title=Palace wing star Bolasie to keep Congo waiting|url=http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/sport.cfm?id=42814&headline=Palace%20wing%20star%20Bolasie%20to%20keep%20Congo%20waiting |accessdate=27 January 2013|work=South London Press|publisher=Tindle Newspapers|date=10 December 2012}} [[Lomana LuaLua]], [[Kazenga LuaLua]] and [[Trésor Kandol]] are his cousins.{{cite news|last=Bailey|first=Graeme|title=Yannick Bolasie set to stay with Crystal Palace rather than play in Africa Cup of Nations| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11706/8265285/Yannick-Bolasie-set-to-stay-with-Crystal-Palace-rather-than-play-in-Africa-Cup-of-Nations|work=Sky Sports|publisher=BSkyB|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=21 November 2012}}{{cite news|last=Happe|first=Liam| title=Kandol glad to be back in the thick of it |url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/sport/4186369.Kandol_glad_to_be_back_in_the_thick_of_it/ |work=News Shopper|publisher=Newsquest|accessdate=27 January 2013|date=9 March 2009}} His younger brother Ruddock Yala is a footballer, who played for Harrow Borough F.C., Grays Athletic F.C., [[Borehamwood F.C.]] and [[Maldon & Tiptree F.C.]].{{cite news |last=Callender Edwards |first=Tyrone |title=OTPN Interview | Ruddock Yala – Grays Athletic (Bolasie's youngest brother) |url=http://www.offthepostnews.co.uk/?p=7387 |work=Off the Post News |publisher= |accessdate=27 January 2013 |date=9 March 2009}} Bolasie holds an active interest in [[Grime (music)|grime music]]. In 2014, he filmed a [[rap battle]] with fellow professional footballer [[Bradley Wright-Phillips]] for the long running grime DVD series Lord of the Mics.{{cite web|url=http://thisisthecut.com/the-return-of-lord-of-the-mics/|title=The Return of Lord of the Mics|last=|first=|date=2014-03-19|website=The Cut|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401070340/http://thisisthecut.com/the-return-of-lord-of-the-mics/|archive-date=2016-04-01|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-12-30}}{{cite (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Sandro Ramírez Castillo''' ({{IPA-es|ˈsandɾo raˈmiɾeθ kasˈtiʎo}}; born 9 July 1995), known simply as '''Sandro''', is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Real Sociedad]] on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].
He began his professional career at [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] playing mainly in their [[FC Barcelona B|reserves]], and won seven domestic and international honours with the first team.
==Club career== ===Barcelona=== [[File:2012 2013 - Sandro Ramírez - Flickr - Castroquini-FCB.jpg|thumb|upright|Sandro playing for [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] in 2012]]
Born in [[Las Palmas]], Canary Islands, Sandro joined [[FC Barcelona]]'s youth setup in 2009, aged 14, after starting out at local [[UD Las Palmas]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sport.es/es/noticias/futbol-base/sandro-ramirez-con-licencia-para-marcar-1197242|title=Sandro Ramírez, con licencia para marcar|trans-title=Sandro Ramírez, licence to score|newspaper=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|location=Barcelona|language=es|date=26 October 2011|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref> On 10 June 2013, he was promoted to [[FC Barcelona B|the former's B-team]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.es/futbol/barca-b/detalle/noticia/siete-juveniles-suben-al-barca-b-para-la-temporada-2013-14|title=Siete juveniles suben al Barça B para la temporada 2013/14|trans-title=Seven youth players promoted to Barça B for 2013/14 season|publisher=FC Barcelona|language=es|date=10 June 2013|accessdate=13 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305011949/http://www.fcbarcelona.es/futbol/barca-b/detalle/noticia/siete-juveniles-suben-al-barca-b-para-la-temporada-2013-14|archivedate=5 March 2016|deadurl=yes}}</ref> and made his professional debut on 17 August in a 1–2 away loss against [[CD Mirandés]] for the [[Segunda División]] championship.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2013/08/17/futbol/equipos/mirandes/1376767969.html|title=Prieto sostiene al Mirandés|trans-title=Prieto sustains Mirandés|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|location=Madrid|language=es|date=17 August 2013|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
Sandro scored his first goal as a professional on 15 September 2013, netting the first of a 2–0 home win against [[Real Madrid Castilla]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2013/09/15/futbol/2adivision/1379246488.html|title=El filial azulgrana se lleva con claridad el 'mini' Clásico |trans-title=Azulgrana reserves clear winners of 'mini' Clásico|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=15 September 2013 |accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> He finished [[2013–14 Segunda División|the campaign]] with 31 appearances, netting seven times to help his team finish third.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.es/futbol/barca-b/detalle/noticia/temporada/2013-2014/todos-los-goles-del-barca-b-2013-14|title=Todos los goles del Barça B 2013–14|trans-title=All 2013–14 Barça B goals|publisher=FC Barcelona|language=es|date=22 June 2014|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>
On 18 August 2014, Sandro scored the last of a 6–0 triumph over [[Club León]] for that year's [[Joan Gamper Trophy]], after [[Assist (football)|assisting]] fellow youth graduate [[Munir El Haddadi]] in the fifth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/match-archive/2014-2015/joan-gamper-trophy/fc-barcelona_leon-f-c|title=FC Barcelona-León F.C|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=18 August 2014|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> He was also called up to the main squad for the match against [[Elche CF]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2014/08/24/futbol/equipos/barcelona/1408873771.html|title=Neymar, baja contra el Elche |trans-title=Neymar, out against Elche|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> but eventually remained unused in the 3–0 [[La Liga]] win on 24 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-divisi%C3%A3%C2%B3n/match/402623/barcelona-elche/report|title=Enrique off to a winning start|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
Sandro made his debut in the [[Spanish football league system|Spanish top level]] on 31 August 2014, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Pedro (footballer, born July 1987)|Pedro]] midway through the second half of the fixture at [[Villarreal CF]] and scoring the game's only goal 12 minutes later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-divisi%C3%A3%C2%B3n/match/402610/villarreal-barcelona/report|title=Sandro Ramirez strikes to give Barcelona victory over Villarreal|publisher=ESPN FC|date=31 August 2014|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> He netted for the first time in the [[UEFA Champions League]] on 21 October, contributing to a [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|3–1 group stage home win]] against [[AFC Ajax]] with an injury-time strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-champions-league/match/405730/barcelona-ajax-amsterdam/report |title=Lionel Messi draws level with Ronaldo as Barcelona cruise past Ajax|publisher=ESPN FC|date=21 October 2014|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> On 16 December, he scored his first goal in the [[Copa del Rey]], in a [[2014–15 Copa del Rey|8–1 home routing]] of [[SD Huesca]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/copa/dieciseisavos/vuelta/bar_hue/|title=Los suplentes culés también cuentan|trans-title=The culé backups also count|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=16 December 2014|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>
On 2 December 2015, in the midst of a lengthy scoring drought for both players,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/munir-hasnt-scored-for-431-days-sandro-317-4630636|title=Munir hasn't scored for 431 days, Sandro 317|newspaper=Sport|location=Barcelona|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3277/la-liga/2015/10/30/16831052/luis-enrique-defends-misfiring-munir-sandro|title=Luis Enrique defends misfiring Munir, Sandro|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref> Sandro scored a [[hat-trick]] and assisted once whilst Munir contributed with a brace in the [[2015–16 Copa del Rey|6–1 home win]] against [[CF Villanovense]] for the domestic cup, to send Barcelona into the [[Single-elimination tournament|round of 16]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34990491|title=Barcelona 6–1 Villanovense|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=2 December 2015|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref> As the former appeared in just ten league games throughout [[2015–16 La Liga|the season]], technical director [[Roberto Fernández Bonillo|Robert Fernández]] announced in May 2016 that the player would leave the club the following month, adding he was only kept in the squad due to a transfer embargo that was to end shortly after.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-spain-fcb-sandro-idUKKCN0YF1XG|title=Striker Sandro to leave Barcelona|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=3 July 2016|accessdate=3 July 2016}}</ref>
===Málaga=== On 2 July 2016, [[Málaga CF]] leaked news of the potential signing of Sandro, and their official website temporarily featured a player profile, shortly after his release from Barcelona.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nuevofutbol.com/2016/07/el-malaga-filtra-el-fichaje-de-sandro-ramirez.html|title=El Málaga filtra el fichaje de Sandro Ramírez|trans-title=Málaga filter signing of Sandro Ramírez|publisher=Nuevo Fútbol|language=es|date=2 July 2016|accessdate=3 July 2016}}</ref> Five days later, they officially announced his signing on a three-year contract.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.malagacf.com/noticia/el-malaga-cf-incorpora-a-sandro-ramirez|title=El Málaga CF incorpora a Sandro Ramírez|trans-title=Málaga CF add Sandro Ramírez|publisher=Málaga CF|language=es|date=7 July 2016|accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 19 August, starting as they began [[2016–17 La Liga|the season]] with a 1–1 draw against [[CA Osasuna]], and scored his first goal four weeks later to equalise in a 2–1 win over [[SD Eibar]] also at [[La Rosaleda Stadium|La Rosaleda]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deia.com/2016/09/21/deportes/futbol/el-malaga-gana-al-eibar-y-elude-la-crisis|title=El Málaga gana al Eibar y elude la crisis|trans-title=Málaga defeat Eibar and avoid crisis|newspaper=[[Deia (newspaper)|Deia]]|location=Bilbao|language=es|date=21 September 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref>
On 8 April 2017, Sandro took his [[2016–17 Málaga CF season|season]] tally to 11 after helping defeat former club Barcelona 2–0 at home, netting the first through a solo effort that started in his own half.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/article/2017/04/09/neymar-sees-red-sandro-shocks-former-club-barca|title=Neymar sees red as Sandro shocks former club Barca|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=9 April 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>
===Everton=== On 3 July 2017, Sandro signed for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a four-year contract after the club triggered a £5.2 million release clause in his Málaga contract.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/03/everton-sign-sandro-ramirez-malaga-spain-under-21|title=Everton complete signing of Burnley defender Michael Keane for £25m|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2715161-sandro-ramirez-completes-everton-transfer-from-malaga-on-4-year-contract|title=Sandro Ramirez completes Everton transfer from Malaga on 4-year contract|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=12 July 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 12 August, starting in a 1–0 home win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40835425|title=Everton 1–0 Stoke City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Alex|last=Bysouth|date=12 August 2017|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
On 30 January 2018, Sandro joined [[Sevilla FC]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of [[2017–18 La Liga|the campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42882208|title=Everton: Sandro Ramirez joins Sevilla as Napoli want Davy Klaassen|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Phil|last=McNulty|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> Exactly seven months later, in the same situation, he moved to [[Real Sociedad]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.realsociedad.eus/en/news/details/agreement-for-sandro-ramirez-to-play-on-loan|title=Agreement for Sandro Ramírez to play on loan|publisher=Real Sociedad|date=30 August 2018|accessdate=30 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Sandro was a member of the [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain under-21 squad]] during the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2017 UEFA European Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-espana.net/64173/spain-reveal-euro-u21-championship-squad|title=Spain reveal U21 Championship squad|publisher=Football España|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> He scored once for the eventual runners-up, in the 3–1 group stage win against [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.as.com/en/2017/06/20/football/1497949717_765343.html|title=Portugal 1–3 Spain: UEFA Under 21 Euro match report, Spain advance to semi-finals|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|location=Madrid|date=20 June 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40451698|title=Germany U21 1–0 Spain U21|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 June 2017|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
==Career statistics== {{updated|<!--match played--> 27 January 2019}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Cuco Martina |image = Audi- quattro-Cup 05.JPG |image_size = 200 |caption = Martina with Southampton in 2015 |fullname = Rhu-endly Aurelio Jean-Carlo Martina{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|9|25|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rotterdam]], Netherlands |height = 1.85 m |position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Right back]] |currentclub = [[Feyenoord]]
(on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]) |clubnumber = 24 |youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Feyenoord]] |years1 = 2008–2011 |clubs1 = [[RBC Roosendaal]] |caps1 = 68 |goals1 = 2 |years2 = 2011–2013 |clubs2 = [[RKC Waalwijk]] |caps2 = 43 |goals2 = 1 |years3 = 2013–2014 |clubs3 = [[Jong FC Twente|Jong Twente]] |caps3 = 11 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2013–2015 |clubs4 = [[FC Twente|Twente]] |caps4 = 48 |goals4 = 1 |years5 = 2015–2017 |clubs5 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |caps5 = 24 |goals5 = 1 |years6 = 2017– |clubs6 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] |caps6 = 21 |goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2018–2019 |clubs7 = → [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] (loan) |caps7 = 17 |goals7 = 0 |years8 = 2019– |clubs8 = → [[Feyenoord]] (loan) |caps8 = 0 |goals8 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2011– |nationalteam1 = [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] |nationalcaps1 = 38 |nationalgoals1 = 1 |club-update = 18:23, 1 January 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 23:03, 10 September 2018 (UTC) }} '''Rhu-endly Aurelio Jean-Carlo''' "'''Cuco'''" '''Martina''' (born 25 September 1989) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Feyenoord]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. He plays primarily as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]], but can also play as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] or [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]]. A youth player at [[Feyenoord]], he began his senior career with [[RBC Roosendaal]] in the [[Eerste Divisie]], followed by two seasons each at [[Eredivisie]] clubs [[RKC Waalwijk]] and [[FC Twente]]. In 2015, he joined [[Premier League]] club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], and two years later [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. Born and raised in the Netherlands, he represents [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] at international level, for whom he is captain. First capped in 2011, he has won the 2017 Caribbean Cup, and he represented the team at the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. ==Early and personal life== Martina was born in [[Rotterdam]]. He grew up in the south of the city with his mother, brothers and sister.{{cite web |url=http://www.twenteinsite.nl/cuco-martina-heet-eigenlijk-rhu-endly.html|title=Cuco Martina heet eigenlijk Rhu-endly|date=27 March 2014|accessdate=7 July 2015| language=Dutch|publisher=Twente Insite}} Martina did not know his father, and states his elder brother was instead like a father to him. His brother [[Javier Martina|Javier]] is also a footballer.{{cite web|url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2015-07-07/in-profile-cuco-martina |title=In Profile: Cuco Martina|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=7 March 2017|publisher=Southampton F.C.}} [[Derwin Martina|Derwin]] is not related to him, despite media reports to the contrary.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39198728|title=Derwin Martina: York City release defender after playing one game for reserve team|date=7 March 2017|accessdate=7 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} ==Club career== ===Netherlands=== Martina played youth football with [[Feyenoord]]. He spent his early senior career with [[RBC Roosendaal]] in the [[Eerste Divisie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vi.nl/spelers/carriere/rhuendly-martina.htm|title=Profile|accessdate=7 July 2015|language=Dutch|publisher=Voetbal International}}{{soccerway|cuco-martina/57652|accessdate=26 June 2017}} In 2011, he joined [[RKC Waalwijk]] of the [[Eredivisie]].{{cite news|last1=Ummels|first1=Jody|title=Overzicht van de Brabantse voetbaltransfers|url=http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/157404722/Overzicht+van+de+Brabantse+voetbaltransfers.aspx|publisher=Omroep Brabant|accessdate=26 August 2017|date=27 June 2011|language=Dutch}} He played 59 official matches in two seasons in [[North Brabant]], scoring to open a 2–0 home win over [[N.E.C. (football club)|N.E.C.]] on 8 December 2012.{{cite news|title=Degelijk RKC Waalwijk verslaat dramatisch NEC: 2–0|url=http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/185050572/Degelijk+RKC+Waalwijk+verslaat+dramatisch+NEC+2-0.aspx|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=Omroep Brabant|date=8 December 2012|language=Dutch}} On 30 July 2013, he joined [[FC Twente]] on a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee.{{cite news|title=Cuco Martina naar FC Twente|url=http://www.fctwente.nl/blog/2013/07/cuco-martina-naar-fc-twente/|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=FC Twente|date=30 July 2013|language=Dutch}} Martina played 59 games across all competitions for the [[Enschede]] club, scoring once: an added-time equaliser in a 2–2 home draw with Feyenoord on 23 February 2014.{{cite news|title=FEYENOORD PEGGED BACK IN INJURY TIME|url=https://www.feyenoord.com/feyenoord-1/results/fc-twente-feyenoord-netherlands-eredivisie-2013-2014/post-match|accessdate=26 August 2017|publisher=Feyenoord|date=23 February 2014}} ===Southampton=== He signed a two-year contract with English club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 7 July 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33426049|title=Cuco Martina: Southampton sign FC Twente defender|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=7 July 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}} An unused substitute in the first leg,{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Adam|title=Southampton 3–0 Vitesse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667103|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 July 2015}} Martina made his Southampton debut in their [[UEFA Europa League]] third qualifying round second leg away to [[SBV Vitesse|Vitesse Arnhem]], playing the full 90 minutes of a 2–0 win on 6 August.{{cite news|last1=Jennings|first1=Patrick|title=Vitesse 0–2 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33738509|accessdate=9 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2015}} Three days later, he made his league debut as a half-time substitute for fellow new signing [[Cédric Soares]] in a 2–2 draw against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Matt|title=Newcastle 2–2 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33750572|accessdate=9 August 2015|date=9 August 2015}} Martina became the first-ever Curaçao international to play for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and the second to play in the [[Premier League]] after [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]'s [[Shelton Martis]] in 2009. On 26 December 2015, on his first start, Martina scored his only goal for the Saints, a long-range strike to open a 4–0 win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He became the first Curaçaoan to score in the Premier League.{{cite news|title=Martina: An unbelievable feeling|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/20151226-cuco-martina-post-southampton-arsenal-2869805.aspx|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=Southampton F.C.|date=26 December 2015}} He was released by Southampton at the end of the 2016–17 season.{{cite web|title=Saints release four players|url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2017-05-25/southampton-2017-retained-list-players-released|publisher=Southampton FC|accessdate=26 May 2017|date=25 May 2017}} ===Everton=== On 17 July 2017, following his release from Southampton, Martina joined fellow [[Premier League]] side [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a three-year deal, reuniting with his former Saints manager [[Ronald Koeman]].{{cite web |title=Blues Swoop For Martina |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/07/17/blues-swoop-for-martina |publisher=Everton Official Site |accessdate=17 July 2017 |date=17 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40637068 |title=Cuco Martina: Everton sign out-of-contract Southampton defender |publisher= BBC Sport |date=17 July 2017 |accessdate=20 July 2017 }} Martina made his league debut for Everton on 12 August, when his club beat [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] 1–0 at [[Goodison Park]].{{cite news |title=Everton 1–0 Stoke City|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40835425 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=12 August 2017}} Martina joined Stoke, newly relegated to the [[EFL Championship]], on a loan for the [[2018–19 Stoke City F.C. season|2018–19]] season.{{cite web |title=Cuco Martina: Stoke City sign Everton defender on a season-long loan deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45224825 |website=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 August 2018}} He made his debut on 25 August, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–0 home win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].{{cite news |title=Stoke City 2–0 Hull City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45229933 |accessdate=17 September 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 August 2018}} Martina's loan with Stoke was cancelled on 31 January 2019,{{cite web |title=Martina returns to Everton |url=https://www.stokecityfc.com/news/martina-returns-to-everton |website=Stoke City |accessdate=31 January 2019}} and he re-joined [[Feyenoord]] on loan for the remainder of the [[2018–19 Feyenoord season|2018–19]] season.{{cite web |title=Martina Makes Feyenoord Loan Switch |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2019/01/31/martina |website=Everton |accessdate=31 January 2019}} ==International career== Martina made his international debut for [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] on 9 August 2011, in their first match since the dissolution of the [[Netherlands Antilles national football team|Netherlands Antilles]]. He played the first half of the 1–0 friendly loss to the [[Dominican Republic national football team|Dominican Republic]] at the [[Estadio Panamericano, San Cristóbal|Estadio Panamericano in San Cristóbal]], before being substituted for [[Kenny Kunst]].{{NFT player|pid=44883|accessdate=7 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rkcwaalwijk.nl/rkc-waalwijk-nieuws/zoet-houdt-weer-de-nul-martina-met-curacao-onderuit/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402130941/http://www.rkcwaalwijk.nl/rkc-waalwijk-nieuws/zoet-houdt-weer-de-nul-martina-met-curacao-onderuit/|title=Zoet houdt weer de nul, Martina met Curaçao onderuit|date=7 September 2011|archivedate=2 April 2012|accessdate=7 July 2015|language=Dutch|publisher=RKC Waalwijk}} He has played in qualifying matches for the 2014 and 2018 World Cups.{{FIFA player|347633}} He served as national team captain.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/who-everton-target-cuco-martina-11793958|title=Who is Everton target Cuco Martina? Everything you need to know|date=24 August 2016|accessdate=15 July 2017|author=Connor O'Neill|publisher=Liverpool Echo}} Martina was part of the Curaçao squad that won the [[2017 Caribbean Cup]] in [[Martinique]], defeating [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] 2–1 in the final.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Sean|title=Boyz edged 1–2 by Curacao in Caribbean Cup final|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/boyz-edged-1-2-by-curacao-in-caribbean-cup-final_103087?profile=1511|accessdate=26 August 2017|date=26 June 2017}} He captained the team at the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].{{cite web|title=Curaçao 2 – 0 Jamaica|url=http://www.concacaf.com/category/gold-cup/game-detail/393983|publisher=CONCACAF|accessdate=26 August 2017}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 1 January 2019}}{{soccerway|cuco-martina/57652|accessdate=18 December 2015}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Oumar Niasse | image = Loko skndrb 10.jpg | caption = Niasse with [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv]] in 2015 | fullname = El Hadji Baye Oumar Niasse{{cite web |title=Aston Villa scouting report: Who is El Hadji Baye Oumar Niasse |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/aston-villa-scouting-report-who-10687949|website=Birmingham Mail |accessdate=21 June 2017|date=5 January 2016}} | height = {{height|m=1.82|precision=0}}{{cite web |title=Player profile: Oumar Niasse |url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/125365/baye--niasse |publisher=ESPN |accessdate=15 July 2017}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|04|18|df=y}}{{cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/players/oumar-niasse-243519/|title=Oumar Niasse|website=11v11.com}} | birth_place = [[Ouakam]], Senegal | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]
(on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]) | clubnumber = 29 | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2008–2013 | clubs1 = [[US Ouakam]] | caps1 = 154 | goals1 = 102 | years2 = 2012 | clubs2 = → [[SK Brann|Brann]] (loan) | caps2 = 3 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2013–2014 | clubs3 = [[Akhisar Belediyespor]] | caps3 = 34 | goals3 = 12 | years4 = 2014–2016 | clubs4 = [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]] | caps4 = 28 | goals4 = 12 | years5 = 2016– | clubs5 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] | caps5 = 31 | goals5 = 8 | years6 = 2017 | clubs6 = → [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] (loan) | caps6 = 17 | goals6 = 4 | years7 = 2019– | clubs7 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan) | caps7 = 7 | goals7 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Senegal national under-23 football team|Senegal U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2013– | nationalteam2 = [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] | nationalcaps2 = 9 | nationalgoals2 = 3 | club-update = 17:12, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 03:10, 6 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''El Hadji Baye Oumar Niasse''' (born 18 April 1990) is a Senegalese professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], on loan from [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and the [[Senegal national football team|Senegal national team]]. Niasse has played top-flight football in Senegal, Norway, Turkey, Russia and England. He won the 2011 [[Senegal Premier League]] with [[US Ouakam|Ouakam]] and scored in [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]]'s win in the [[2015 Russian Cup Final]]. He signed for Everton for a £13.5 million transfer fee in 2016. Niasse made his full international debut for Senegal in 2013. ==Club career== ===Ouakam=== Born in [[Ouakam]], [[Dakar Department]], Niasse began his football career with hometown club [[US Ouakam]] in the second tier. He signed his first professional contract with Ouakam in 2008 and in the 2008–09 season helped his team win the Second League title by scoring 21 goals.{{cite web|url=http://www.fanatik.com.tr/2014/01/09/gol-silahi-oumar-niasse-350690|title=Gol silahı Oumar Niasse}} Playing as a winger, Niasse also played a key role in Ouakam winning the [[Senegal Premier League]] title in 2011.{{Cite web|title = Oumar Niasse: Meet the hard-working Senegalese striker wanted in England|url = http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/oumar-niasse-meet-hard-working-senegalese-striker-wanted-england#:0solhCmynml5YA|website = FourFourTwo|accessdate = 2 February 2016|date = 8 January 2016}} Niasse started a trial with Norwegian club [[SK Brann|Brann]] in February 2012,[http://www.ba.no/sport/fotball/brann/article5907691.ece Han kan være Branns nye kantspiller] ba.no {{no icon}} and after impressing signed for the club on a six-month loan.[http://fotball.aftenposten.no/blogg/doddo/article223554.ece Doddo-bloggen: Signér Niasse!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212095503/http://fotball.aftenposten.no/blogg/doddo/article223554.ece |date=12 February 2012 }} aftenposten.no {{no icon}}[http://www.brann.no/nyheter/er-her-for-a-bli-bedre/ – Er her for å bli bedre] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120223060545/http://www.brann.no/nyheter/er-her-for-a-bli-bedre/ |date=23 February 2012 }} brann.no {{no icon}} His time in Norway was hampered by poor form and injuries, and he returned to Senegal after playing just three [[Tippeligaen]] matches. ===Akhisar Belediyespor=== After a trial period with French club [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]], Niasse was offered a contract to join the club but refused the offer.{{Citation needed|date = January 2016}} He joined the summer camp of Turkish [[Süper Lig]] club [[Akhisar Belediyespor]] and signed permanently with them in August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.yazete.com/spor/akhisarda-oumar-niasse-de-tamam-660796.html|title=Akhisar'da Oumar Niasse de tamam}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fanatik.com.tr/2013/08/08/akhisara-senegalli-328718|title=Akhisar'a Senegalli}} Niasse scored on his debut in Turkey and ultimately finished the season with 15 goals. ===Lokomotiv Moscow=== [[File:Loco-Terec (4).jpg|thumb|Niasse in action for Lokomotiv against [[FC Akhmat Grozny|Terek Grozny]] in October 2014]] Before the 2014–15 season, Niasse signed with Russian club [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]] in July 2014 for a €5.5 million transfer fee. He scored Lokomotiv's equalising goal in the [[2015 Russian Cup Final|Russian Cup Final]] against [[FC Kuban Krasnodar|Kuban Krasnodar]] on 21 May 2015 as his side went on to win 3–1 after extra time.{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/05/21/russia/cup/fk-lokomotiv-moscow/fc-kuban-krasnodar/2031399/ |accessdate=12 January 2016 |title=Lokomotiv Moskva vs. Kuban' Krasnodar 3 – 1 |website=Soccerway}} ===Everton=== Niasse joined English [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 1 February 2016 for a transfer fee of approximately £13.5 million, signing a four-and-a-half year contract.{{cite web|publisher=[[Everton F.C.]]|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2016/02/01/niasse-completes-13-5-move|title=Niasse Completes £13.5m Move|date=1 February 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jan/30/oumar-niasse-everton-lokomotiv-moscow-premier-league|title=Everton poised to sign Lokomotiv Moscow's Oumar Niasse for £13.5m|first=David|last=Hytner|date=30 January 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}} He made his debut for the club against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] on 20 February 2016, entering as an 80th-minute substitute for striker [[Romelu Lukaku]]. After 152 minutes of football in his first season at the club, Niasse was not given a squad number for the following 2016–17 season.{{cite news|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/aug/03/premier-league-2016-17-preview-everton|title=Premier League 2016–17 Preview Everton|date=3 August 2016}} He was informed by then-Everton manager [[Ronald Koeman]] he would need to search for a new club during the summer 2016 transfer window, saying, "[I]f Niasse likes to play football he needs to leave Everton."{{cite news|last1=Bascombe|first1=Chris|title=Everton manager Ronald Koeman tells Oumar Niasse to find another club – just six months after his arrival|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/08/18/everton-manager-ronald-koeman-tells-oumar-niasse-to-find-another/|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=18 August 2016}} However, following the close of the transfer deadline for loaning and signing players in England, he was listed as part of the 25-man Everton squad for the 2016–17 season submitted on 1 September 2016{{cite news|last1=Doyle|first1=Ian|title=Oumar Niasse included in Everton's Premier League squad|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/oumar-niasse-included-evertons-premier-11831437|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=Liverpool Echo|date=1 September 2016}} and eventually issued squad number 24. In October 2016, Niasse was demoted to the under-23 squad and had his personal locker revoked.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/11/everton-oumar-niasse-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez|title=Everton’s Oumar Niasse: ‘It’s really sad. I don’t think I deserve this’ |last=Hytner|first=David|date=11 October 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|accessdate=21 October 2016}} ====Loan to Hull City==== On 13 January 2017, Niasse signed a loan contract with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] until the end of the 2016–17 season with an option for a £10 million permanent transfer from Everton.{{Cite news |first =David|last=Anderson |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/everton-flop-oumar-niasse-joins-9615346|title=Everton flop Oumar Niasse joins Hull on loan with view to permanent £10m switch |date=13 January 2017 |newspaper=The Mirror|accessdate=13 January 2017}}{{cite news|title=Hull City sign Oumar Niasse on loan and Evandro for undisclosed fee |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38611524 |newspaper=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 January 2017|date=13 January 2017}} He made his debut the next day as an 83rd-minute substitute for [[Abel Hernández]] in a 3–1 home win against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38539371 | title = Hull City 3–1 Bournemouth | date = 14 January 2017 | publisher = BBC Sport | accessdate = 14 January 2017}} His first goal for Hull and in English football came on 26 January in the [[EFL Cup]] semi-final second leg against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], where he made his first start for the club. Hull won the second leg 2–1 but ultimately lost the tie 3–2 on aggregate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38672990|title=Hull City 2–1 Manchester United (Agg: 2–3)|date=26 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 January 2017}} Niasse scored his first Premier League goal in a 2–0 victory against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 4 February.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38779233 | title = Hull City 2–0 Liverpool | date = 4 February 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate = 4 February 2017}} On 11 March, he came on as a substitute against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and scored both goals in a 2–1 victory.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39163820 | title = Hull City 2–1 Swansea City | date = 11 March 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate = 11 March 2017}} Hull were relegated to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] at the end of the season and opted not to exercise its option to outright purchase Niasse.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/everton-aim-sell-oumar-niasse-13218336|website=Liverpool Echo|date=21 June 2017|accessdate=1 July 2017|title=Everton aim to sell Oumar Niasse this summer as attack revamp goes on}} ====Return to Everton==== After returning to Everton, Niasse made his first appearance since his return as a substitute in the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] third round match against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] at [[Goodison Park]] on 20 September 2017, scoring Everton's third goal of a 3–0 win.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41249724|title= Everton 3–0 Sunderland|accessdate = 21 September 2017|newspaper= BBC Sport|date= 20 September 2017}} Manager Ronald Koeman named Niasse in Everton's 25-man Premier League squad upon his return from loan and consequently issued him a squad number. However, Koeman omitted Niasse from Everton's [[UEFA Europa League]] squad.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/27/everton-ronald-koeman-europa-league|title=Everton’s Koeman has no regrets over Oumar Niasse’s Europa League snub|work=The Guardian|date=27 September 2017}} On 23 September, Niasse scored two goals against AFC Bournemouth in a 2–1 Premier League win, helping Everton to come back from a goal down.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41290322|title= Everton 2–1 Bournemouth|accessdate = 23 September 2017|newspaper= BBC Sport|date= 23 September 2017}} On 5 November, Niasse scored Everton's first goal in a 3–2 home win against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], having been losing 2–0.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41792811|title=Everton 3–2 Watford|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 November 2017}} Thirteen days later, he scored in a 2–2 draw away to bottom side [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41951923|title=Crystal Palace 2–2 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=18 November 2017}} Niasse sparked controversy in the match by appearing to dive to win Everton a penalty, which was converted by [[Leighton Baines]] to make the score 1–1 in the first half.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/oumar-niasse-facing-retrospective-diving-ban-after-winning-contentious-penalty-at-crystal-palace-a3695611.html|title=Oumar Niasse facing retrospective diving ban after winning contentious penalty at Crystal Palace|work=London Evening Standard|date=18 November 2017}} He subsequently became the first Premier League player to be charged with "successful deception of a match official" under [[The Football Association]]'s new regulations.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42066734|title=Oumar Niasse: Everton striker charged for dive against Crystal Palace|newspaper=BBC Sport|date=21 November 2017|accessdate=21 November 2017}} Everton appealed the verdict, but the FA rejected the appeal and Niasse received a two-match suspension.{{Cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/11138846/evertons-oumar-niasse-has-appeal-to-simulation-ban-rejected-by-fa|title=Niasse given two-match ban for diving|publisher=Sky Sports|date=22 November 2017|accessdate=22 November 2017}} ====Loan to Cardiff City==== On 18 January 2019, Niasse joined fellow Premier League team [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan for the remainder of the season.{{cite news |title=Loan: Niasse is a Bluebird |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2019/january/loan-oumar-niasse-is-a-bluebird/ |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=18 January 2018 |accessdate=18 January 2018}} ==International career== Niasse was first selected for the [[Senegal national football team|Senegal national team]] in January 2013 as part of an all domestic-based squad.{{cite news|title=Sénégal-Chili : Demba Ramata Ndiaye publie une liste de 18 locaux|url=http://www.ndamli.sn/index.php/football/9368-senegal-chili-demba-ramata-ndiaye-publie-une-liste-de-18-locaux|accessdate=20 October 2017|publisher=Ndamli|date=8 January 2013|language=French}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He made his debut on 15 January, starting in a 2–1 friendly loss to [[Chile national football team|Chile]] in [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]].{{cite news|title=Sénégal – Chili : 1–2|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Senegal-chili-1-2/342763|accessdate=20 October 2017|work=L'Equipe|date=16 January 2013|language=French}} On 25 May 2015, Niasse scored his first international goals, a brace in a 3–1 win over [[Kosovo national football team|Kosovo]] at the [[Stade de Genève]].{{cite news|title=Amical Kosovo 1–3 Sénégal : Baye Oumar Niasse et Diafra Sakho mettent fin à la série de nuls des « Lions »|url=http://www.pressafrik.com/Amical-Kosovo-1-3-Senegal-Baye-Oumar-Niasse-et-Diafra-Sakho-mettent-fin-a-la-serie-de-nuls-des-Lions_a122698.html|accessdate=20 October 2017|publisher=Press Afrik|date=25 May 2015|language=French}} ==Personal life== His brother [[Ibrahima Niasse]] is also a professional footballer.{{cite news |last1=Hunter |first1=Andy |title=Everton’s Oumar Niasse: ‘I am a fighter, someone who always wants the ball’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/11/everton-oumar-niasse-fighter-fa-cup |accessdate=1 March 2019 |work=The Guardian |date=11 March 2016}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 9 March 2019}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club
